is a professional [[Association football|football]] club based in [[London]], England, that competes in the [[Premier League]], the highest tier of [[Football in England|English football]]. The club has won eight League titles, eight [[FA Cup]]s, five [[EFL Cup|League Cup]]s, four [[FA Community Shield]]s, two [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]]s, one [[UEFA Champions League]], one [[UEFA Europa League]], and one [[UEFA Super Cup]].<ref name="Chelsea win breaks London duck">{{cite news |title=Chelsea win breaks London duck |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=1798274.html#chelseas+capital+gains |work=Union of European Football Associations |date=20 May 2012 |accessdate=20 May 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/news/story/_/id/1449255/ivanovic-goal-wins-europa-league-chelsea?cc=5901 |title=Chelsea wins Europa on Ivanovic header |publisher=ESPNFC |date=16 May 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=1947872.html |title=Chelsea join illustrious trio |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=17 May 2013 }}</ref>
Founded in 1905, the club's home ground since then has been [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]].<ref name="capacity">{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/the-club/about-chelsea-football-club/general-club-info.html |title=General Club Information |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref> Chelsea won its only [[Football League First Division|First Division]] title in [[1954–55 Chelsea F.C. season|1955]], but saw limited success in various cup competitions until 2003, when the club was purchased by Russian billionaire [[Roman Abramovich]].<ref name="takeover">{{cite news |title=Russian businessman buys Chelsea |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3036838.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 July 2003 |accessdate=11 February 2007 }}</ref> Chelsea then saw heavy investment, and have since won eighteen honours under Abramovich.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/about-chelsea/history/trophy-cabinet |title=Trophy Cabinet |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 May 2018 |df=dmy }}</ref>
[[José Mourinho]] is the club's most successful manager in terms of the number of major honours won, and his title-winning team set an English record for points between 2004 and 2005.{{refn|group=note|Chelsa's record number of points (95) in the 2004–05 season was broken by [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] (100) in the 2017–18 season.}} Chelsea have traditionally wore a royal blue kit with white socks, and the club's crest features a ceremonial lion rampant regardant holding a staff.<ref name="new crest">{{cite news |title=Chelsea centenary crest unveiled |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/4008257.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 November 2004 |accessdate=2 January 2007 }}</ref> The club have rivalries with neighbouring clubs [[West London derby|Fulham]], [[Arsenal F.C.–Chelsea F.C. rivalry|Arsenal]], and [[Chelsea F.C.–Tottenham Hotspur F.C. rivalry|Tottenham Hotspur]].
In terms of club value, Chelsea are the [[Forbes' list of the most valuable football clubs|seventh most valuable football club in the world]], worth £1.54 billion ($2.06 billion), and are the [[Deloitte Football Money League|eighth highest-earning]] football club in the world, with earnings of over €428 million in the 2017–18 season.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikeozanian/2018/06/12/the-worlds-most-valuable-soccer-teams-2018/#3dddb7c845c8|title=The World's Most Valuable Soccer Teams 2018|last=Ozanian|first=Mike|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www2.deloitte.com/uk/en/pages/sports-business-group/articles/deloitte-football-money-league.html|title=Deloitte Football Money League 2018|date=23 January 2018|accessdate=23 January 2018|publisher=Deloitte}}</ref> Based on attendance figures, the club have the sixth-largest fanbase in England.<ref name="All-time attendance">{{cite web|title=All Time League Attendance Records|url=http://www.nufc.com/2015-16html/attendance-all-time.html|publisher=nufc.com|accessdate=6 April 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406083542/http://www.nufc.com/2015-16html/attendance-all-time.html|archivedate=6 April 2016|date=22 September 2015}} Please note, pre-war figures come from unreliable sources.</ref>
==History== {{Main|History of Chelsea F.C.}} [[File:Chelsea Team 1905.jpg|thumb|250px|The [[History of Chelsea F.C.|first Chelsea team]] in September 1905]]
In 1904, [[Gus Mears]] acquired the [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] athletics stadium with the aim of turning it into a football ground. An offer to lease it to nearby [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] was turned down, so Mears opted to found his own club to use the stadium. As there was already a team named Fulham in the borough, the name of the adjacent borough of [[Metropolitan Borough of Chelsea|Chelsea]] was chosen for the new club; names like ''Kensington FC'', ''Stamford Bridge FC'' and ''London FC'' were also considered.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=55}}</ref> Chelsea were founded on 10 March 1905 at The Rising Sun pub (now The Butcher's Hook),<ref name="teamhistory"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/the-club/club-history/1900.html|title=The Birth of a Club|publisher=Chelsea FC|date=30 September 2004|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> opposite the present-day main entrance to the ground on [[Fulham Road]], and were elected to the Football League shortly afterwards.
The club won promotion to the First Division in their second season, and yo-yoed between the First and Second Divisions in their early years. They reached the [[1915 FA Cup Final]], where they lost to [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] at Old Trafford, and finished third in the First Division in 1920, the club's best league campaign to that point.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1800262 |title=Team History – 1905–29 |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718071312/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/TeamHistory/0%2C%2C10268~1800262%2C00.html |archivedate=18 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Chelsea attracted large crowds<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/page/TeamHistory/0,,10268~910883,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120720222638/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/TeamHistory/0%2C%2C10268~910883%2C00.html |archivedate=20 July 2012 |title=Between the Wars – Big Names and Big Crowds |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=7 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> and had a reputation for signing big-name players,<ref name="glanville">{{cite news |date=10 January 2004 |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article992039.ece |title=Little sign of change for Chelsea and their impossible dreams |work=The Times |location=UK|accessdate=15 March 2009 |first=Brian |last=Glanville |author-link=Brian Glanville}} {{registration required}}</ref> but success continued to elude the club in the inter-war years.
Former [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and England centre-forward [[Ted Drake]] became manager in 1952 and proceeded to modernise the club. He removed the club's [[Chelsea pensioner]] crest, improved the youth set-up and training regime, rebuilt the side with shrewd signings from the lower divisions and amateur leagues, and led Chelsea to their first major trophy success – the League championship – in [[1954–55 Chelsea F.C. season|1954–55]]. The following season saw UEFA create the [[UEFA Champions League|European Champions' Cup]], but after objections from [[The Football League]] and the [[The Football Association|FA]] Chelsea were persuaded to withdraw from the competition before it started.<ref>{{cite news |date=27 April 2005 |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/sport/football/europe/article2327902.ece |title=The great Chelsea surrender |work=The Times |location=UK |accessdate=29 December 2006 |first=Brian |last=Glanville |author-link=Brian Glanville}}</ref> Chelsea failed to build on this success, and spent the remainder of the 1950s in mid-table. Drake was dismissed in 1961 and replaced by player-coach [[Tommy Docherty]].
[[File:ChelseaFC League Performance.svg|thumb|left|Chart showing the progress of Chelsea's league finishes from 1906 to the present]]
Docherty built a new team around the group of talented young players emerging from the club's youth set-up and Chelsea challenged for honours throughout the 1960s, enduring several near-misses. They were on course for a treble of League, FA Cup and League Cup going into the final stages of the 1964–65 season, winning the League Cup but faltering late on in the other two.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography – The Definitive Story of the First 100 Years|publisher=Headline Book Publishing Ltd|year=2006|isbn=978-0-7553-1466-9 |page=196}}</ref> In three seasons the side were beaten in three major semi-finals and were FA Cup runners-up. Under Docherty's successor, [[Dave Sexton]], Chelsea won the [[1970 FA Cup Final|FA Cup in 1970]], beating [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] 2–1 in a final replay. Chelsea took their first European honour, a [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] triumph, the following year, with another replayed win, this time over [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] in Athens.
The late 1970s through to the '80s was a turbulent period for Chelsea. An ambitious redevelopment of Stamford Bridge threatened the financial stability of the club,<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=84–87}}</ref> star players were sold and the team were relegated. Further problems were caused by a notorious [[hooliganism|hooligan]] element among the support, which was to plague the club throughout the decade.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=143–157}}</ref> In 1982, Chelsea were, at the nadir of their fortunes, acquired by [[Ken Bates]] for the nominal sum of £1, although by now the Stamford Bridge freehold had been sold to property developers, meaning the club faced losing their home.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=89–90}}</ref> On the pitch, the team had fared little better, coming close to relegation to the [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] for the first time, but in 1983 manager [[John Neal (footballer, born 1932)|John Neal]] put together an impressive new team for minimal outlay. Chelsea won the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] title in 1983–84 and established themselves in the top division, before being relegated again in 1988. The club bounced back immediately by winning the Second Division championship in 1988–89.
[[File:Chelsea UCL Winners 2012.jpg|thumb|250px|Chelsea players celebrate their first [[2012 UEFA Champions League Final|UEFA Champions League title]] against [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] (2012).]]
After a long-running legal battle, Bates reunited the stadium freehold with the club in 1992 by doing a deal with the banks of the property developers, who had been bankrupted by a market crash.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=90–91}}</ref> Chelsea's form in the new Premier League was unconvincing, although they did reach the [[1994 FA Cup Final]] with [[Glenn Hoddle]]. It was not until the appointment of [[Ruud Gullit]] as player-manager in 1996 that their fortunes changed. He added several top international players to the side, as the club [[1997 FA Cup Final|won the FA Cup in 1997]] and established themselves as one of England's top sides again. Gullit was replaced by [[Gianluca Vialli]], who led the team to victory in the [[1998 Football League Cup Final|League Cup Final]], the [[1998 UEFA Cup Winners' Cup Final|UEFA Cup Winners' Cup Final]] and the [[1998 UEFA Super Cup|UEFA Super Cup]] in 1998, the [[2000 FA Cup Final|FA Cup in 2000]] and their first appearance in the [[UEFA Champions League]]. Vialli was sacked in favour of [[Claudio Ranieri]], who guided Chelsea to the [[2002 FA Cup Final]] and Champions League qualification in 2002–03.
In July 2003, Bates sold Chelsea to Russian billionaire [[Roman Abramovich]] for £140 million.<ref name="takeover"/> Over £100 million was spent on new players, but Ranieri was unable to deliver any trophies,<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea sack Ranieri |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/3742477.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 June 2004 |accessdate=20 May 2012 }}</ref> and was replaced by [[José Mourinho]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea appoint Mourinho |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/3765263.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 June 2004 |accessdate=20 May 2012 }}</ref> Under Mourinho, Chelsea became the fifth English team to win back-to-back league championships since the Second World War ([[2004–05 FA Premier League|2004–05]] and [[2005–06 FA Premier League|2005–06]]),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sportinglife.com/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/06/03/12/SOCCER_Chelsea.html&TEAMHD=soccer |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603160253/http://www.sportinglife.com/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer%2F06%2F03%2F12%2FSOCCER_Chelsea.html&TEAMHD=soccer |archivedate=3 June 2012 |title=Terry Eyes Back-to-Back Titles |work=Sporting Life |accessdate=22 January 2007 |first=Matt |last=Barlow |date=12 March 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> in addition to winning an FA Cup ([[2007 FA Cup Final|2007]]) and two League Cups ([[2005 Football League Cup Final|2005]] and [[2007 Football League Cup Final|2007]]). After a poor start to the 2007–2008 season, Mourinho was replaced by [[Avram Grant]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea name Grant as new manager |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/7004083.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 September 2007 |accessdate=21 September 2007 }}</ref> who led the club to their first [[2008 UEFA Champions League Final|UEFA Champions League final]], which they lost on penalties to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].
[[Luiz Felipe Scolari]] took over from Grant, but was sacked after 7 months following poor results. [[Guus Hiddink]] then took over the club on an interim basis while continuing to manage the [[Russian national football team]]. Hiddink guided Chelsea to another [[2009 FA Cup Final|FA Cup success]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea 2–1 Everton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/8060989.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 May 2009 |accessdate=1 June 2009 }}</ref> after which he left the club to return full-time to the Russian managerial position. In [[2009–10 in English football|2009–10]], his successor [[Carlo Ancelotti]] led them to their first [[2009–10 Premier League|Premier League]] and [[2010 FA Cup Final|FA Cup]] [[Double (association football)|Double]]", the team becoming the first English top-flight club to score 100 league goals in a season since [[1962–63 in English football|1963]].<ref name="Wigan80">{{cite news |title=Chelsea 8–0 Wigan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8663686.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 May 2010 |accessdate=16 May 2010 }}</ref> In 2012, caretaker manager [[Roberto Di Matteo]] led Chelsea to their seventh [[2012 FA Cup Final|FA Cup]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea 2–1 Liverpool |first=Phil |last=McNulty |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17878435 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 May 2012 |accessdate=20 May 2012 }}</ref> and their first [[2012 UEFA Champions League Final|UEFA Champions League title]], beating [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] 4–3 on penalties,<ref name="final2012">{{cite news |title=Bayern Munich 1–1 Chelsea (aet, 4–3 pens) |first=Phil |last=McNulty |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18044385 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 May 2012 |accessdate=20 May 2012 }}</ref> the first London club to win the trophy.<ref name="final2012"/> In 2013, interim manager [[Rafael Benítez]] guided Chelsea to win the [[2013 UEFA Europa League Final|UEFA Europa League]] against [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Benfica 1–2 Chelsea |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22445388 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 May 2013 |accessdate=15 May 2013 }}</ref> helping them become the first club to hold two major European titles simultaneously and one of [[UEFA club competition records#List of teams to have won the three main European club competitions|five clubs]], and the first British club followed by [[Manchester United FC|Manchester United]], to have won all three of [[UEFA]]'s major club competitions.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea claim last-gasp Europa League triumph |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hvKoBXa2illaBsY08MgEqORVvLkQ?docId=CNG.ed0a8f81bd5745978904d66a17caa38a.721 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227204142/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hvKoBXa2illaBsY08MgEqORVvLkQ?docId=CNG.ed0a8f81bd5745978904d66a17caa38a.721 |archivedate=27 February 2014 |agency=Agence France-Presse |date=15 May 2013 |accessdate=3 August 2013 }}</ref> In the summer of 2013, Mourinho returned as manager, leading Chelsea to [[2015 Football League Cup Final|League Cup]] success in March 2015,<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea 2–0 Tottenham Hotspur |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31572594 |publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 March 2015 |accessdate=13 April 2015 }}</ref> and their fifth league title two months later.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McNulty|first1=Phil|title=Chelsea 1–0 Crystal Palace|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32471261|accessdate=4 May 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=3 May 2015}}</ref> Mourinho was removed after four months of the following season, with the club having lost 9 of their first 16 games and sitting only one point above the relegation zone.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34670192|title=Jose Mourinho: Chelsea sack boss after Premier League slump|date=17 December 2015|publisher= BBC Sport}}</ref> [[2016–17 Chelsea F.C. season|Two years later]], under new coach [[Antonio Conte]], Chelsea won its sixth English title.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2017/may/12/west-brom-v-chelsea-blues-bid-to-win-premier-league-title-live|title=Chelsea crowned Premier League champions after win at West Brom – as it happened|date=12 May 2017|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
==Stadium== {{Main|Stamford Bridge (stadium)}} [[File:Stamford Bridge - West Stand.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], West Stand]] Chelsea have only had one home ground, Stamford Bridge, where they have played since the team's foundation. It was officially opened on 28 April 1877 and for the first 28 years of its existence it was used almost exclusively by the [[London Athletic Club]] as an arena for athletics meetings and not at all for football. In 1904 the ground was acquired by businessman [[Gus Mears]] and his brother [[Joseph Mears|Joseph]], who had also purchased nearby land (formerly a large market garden) with the aim of staging football matches on the now 12.5 acre (51,000 m²) site.<ref name="stadium"/> Stamford Bridge was designed for the Mears family by the noted football architect [[Archibald Leitch]], who had also designed [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox]], [[Craven Cottage]] and [[Hampden Park]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=69–71}}</ref> Most football clubs were founded first, and then sought grounds in which to play, but Chelsea were founded for Stamford Bridge.
Starting with an open bowl-like design and one covered terrace, Stamford Bridge had an original capacity of around 100,000.<ref name="stadium"/> The early 1930s saw the construction of a terrace on the southern part of the ground with a roof that covered around one fifth of the stand. It eventually became known as the "Shed End", the home of Chelsea's most loyal and vocal supporters, particularly during the 1960s, 70s and 80s. The exact origins of the name are unclear, but the fact that the roof looked like a corrugated iron shed roof played a part.<ref name="stadium">{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/page/StadiumHistory/0,,10268,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512170633/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/StadiumHistory/0%2C%2C10268%2C00.html |archivedate=12 May 2012 |title=Stadium History – Introduction |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=20 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
In the early 1970s, the club's owners announced a modernisation of Stamford Bridge with plans for a state-of-the-art 50,000 all-seater stadium.<ref name="stadium"/> Work began on the East Stand in 1972 but the project was beset with problems and was never completed; the cost brought the club close to bankruptcy, culminating in the [[Fee simple|freehold]] being sold to property developers. Following a long legal battle, it was not until the mid-1990s that Chelsea's future at the stadium was secured and renovation work resumed.<ref name="stadium"/> The north, west and southern parts of the ground were converted into all-seater stands and moved closer to the pitch, a process completed by 2001.
When Stamford Bridge was redeveloped in the [[Ken Bates|Bates]] era many additional features were added to the complex including two hotels, apartments, bars, restaurants, the Chelsea Megastore, and an interactive visitor attraction called Chelsea World of Sport. The intention was that these facilities would provide extra revenue to support the football side of the business, but they were less successful than hoped and before the Abramovich takeover in 2003 the debt taken on to finance them was a major burden on the club. Soon after the takeover a decision was taken to drop the "Chelsea Village" brand and refocus on Chelsea as a football club. However, the stadium is sometimes still referred to as part of ''"Chelsea Village"'' or ''"The Village"''. [[File:Chelsea-ilkmac.jpg|left|frame|Chelsea ''vs.'' [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] at Stamford Bridge on 23 September 1905; Chelsea won 1–0.]] The Stamford Bridge [[Freehold (law)|freehold]], the [[Association football pitch|pitch]], the turnstiles and Chelsea's [[naming rights]] are now owned by [[Chelsea Pitch Owners]], a non-profit organisation in which fans are the shareholders. The CPO was created to ensure the stadium could never again be sold to developers. As a condition for using the Chelsea FC name, the club has to play its first team matches at Stamford Bridge, which means that if the club moves to a new stadium, they may have to change their name.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=91–92}}</ref> Chelsea's [[Cobham Training Centre|training ground]] is located in [[Cobham, Surrey]]. Chelsea moved to Cobham in 2004. Their previous training ground in [[Harlington, London|Harlington]] was taken over by [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|QPR]] in 2005.<ref>{{cite news |title=QPR take over Chelsea training ground |first=Wayne |last=Veysey |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/qpr-take-over-chelsea-training-ground-7179619.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025213214/http://www.standard.co.uk/sport/qpr-take-over-chelsea-training-ground-7179619.html |archivedate=25 October 2012 |work=London Evening Standard |date=24 May 2005 |accessdate=24 June 2009 }}</ref> The new training facilities in Cobham were completed in 2007.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea's new training ground for the future |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/london/content/articles/2007/07/05/chelsea_ground_feature.shtml |publisher=BBC London |date=5 July 2007 |accessdate=24 June 2009 }}</ref>
Stamford Bridge has been used for a variety of other sporting events since 1905. It hosted the [[FA Cup Final]] from 1920 to 1922,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/TheFACup/FACompetitions/TheFACup/History/CupFinalResults |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120516005522/http://thefa.com/Competitions/FACompetitions/TheFACup/History/CupFinalResults |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 May 2012 |title=Cup Final Statistics |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=18 February 2011 }}</ref> has held ten [[FA Cup Semi-finals]] (most recently in [[1977–78 FA Cup|1978]]), ten [[FA Community Shield|FA Charity Shield]] matches (the last in [[1970 FA Charity Shield|1970]]), and three [[England national football team|England international]] matches, the last in 1932; it was also the venue for an unofficial ''Victory International'' in 1946.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/MatchRsl/MatchRslUnoff.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110122110105/http://www.englandfootballonline.com/MatchRsl/MatchRslUnoff.html |archivedate=22 January 2011 |title=England's Matches: Unofficial |url=http://www.uefa.com/womenschampionsleague/season=2013/finals/index.html |title=2013 final: Stamford Bridge |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref> [[File:West Stand |accessdate=18 February 2011}}</ref> It was the venue for a [[boxing]] match between world [[flyweight]] champion [[Jimmy Wilde]] and Joe Conn in 1918.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/casey/MC_Wilde.htm |title=Jimmy Wilde: The Original Explosive Thin Man |publisher=Cyberboxingzone.com |accessdate=18 February 2011}}</ref> The running track was used for [[dirt track racing]] between 1928 and 1932,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.guskuhn.net/GKuhn/Stamford%20Bridge/StamfordBrdgIndex.htm |title=Stamford Bridge Speedway |publisher=guskuhn.net |accessdate=18 February 2011}}</ref> [[greyhound racing]] from 1933 to 1968, and [[Midget car racing]] in 1948.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.speedcarworld.com.au/default.asp?Page=Release&Id=8958|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325010050/http://www.speedcarworld.com.au/default.asp?Page=Release&Id=8958|archivedate=25 March 2012|title=U.S. Invades England 1948|publisher=speedcarworld.com|accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref> In 1980, Stamford Bridge hosted the first international [[Floodlights (sport)|floodlit]] |accessdate=18 February 2011}}</ref> It was also the home stadium of the [[London Monarchs]] [[American Football]] team for the [[1997 London Monarchs season|1997 season]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britballnow.co.uk/History/Britball%20Teams/LONDONMONARCHS.htm|title=London Monarchs|publisher=Britballnow.co.uk|accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref> The current club ownership have stated that a larger stadium is necessary in order for Chelsea to stay competitive with rival clubs who have significantly larger stadia, such as Arsenal and Manchester United.<ref>{{cite news |date=25 April 2012 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17839225 |title=Chelsea chief: We will drop out of Europe's elite without new stadium |publisher=BBC |accessdate=6 May 2012}}</ref> Owing to its location next to a main road and two railway lines, fans can only enter the ground via the [[Fulham Road]] exits, which places constraints on expansion due to [[Occupational safety and health|health and safety]] regulations.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=76 }}</ref> The club have consistently affirmed their |url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/2006/0412/stamfordbridge.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215050229/http://www.rte.ie/sport/2006/0412/stamfordbridge.html?rss |archivedate=15 December 2007 ==Crest and colours==
===Crest===
Chelsea have had four main [[crest (sports)|crests]], which all underwent minor variations. The first, adopted when the club was founded, was the image of a [[Chelsea pensioner]], the army veterans who reside at the nearby [[Royal Hospital Chelsea]]. This contributed to the club's original "pensioner" nickname, and remained for the next half-century, though it never appeared on the shirts. When [[Ted Drake]] became Chelsea manager in 1952, he began to modernise the club. Believing the Chelsea pensioner crest to be old-fashioned, he insisted that it be replaced.<ref name="crest">{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=42}}</ref> A stop-gap badge which comprised the initials C.F.C. was adopted for a year. In 1953, the club crest was changed to an upright blue lion looking backwards and holding a [[crosier|staff]]. It was based on elements in the [[coat of arms]] of the [[Metropolitan Borough of Chelsea]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.civicheraldry.co.uk/lcc.html#chelsea%20bc |title=Chelsea Metropolitan Borough Council |work=Civic Heraldry of England and Wales |accessdate=21 January 2007}}</ref> with the "lion rampant regardant" taken from the arms of then club president [[William Cadogan, 7th Earl Cadogan|Viscount Chelsea]] and the staff from the [[Westminster Abbey|Abbots of Westminster]], former Lords of the Manor of Chelsea. It also featured three red roses, to represent England, and two footballs.<ref name="crest"/> This was the first Chelsea crest to appear on the shirts, in the early 1960s.
In 1986, with [[Ken Bates]] now owner of the club, Chelsea's crest was changed again as part of another attempt to modernise and because the old rampant lion badge could not be trademarked.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/the-club/club-history/1980.html |title=1980s Summary |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> The new badge featured a more naturalistic non-heraldic lion, in white and not blue, standing over the C.F.C. initials. This lasted for the next 19 years, with some modifications such as the use of different colours, including red from 1987 to 1995, and yellow from 1995 until 1999, before the white returned.<ref name="HFK">{{cite web|title=Historical Kits – Chelsea |url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Chelsea/Chelsea.htm |first=Dave |last=Moor |publisher=Historical Kits |accessdate=28 September 2011}}</ref> With the new ownership of [[Roman Abramovich]], and the club's centenary approaching, combined with demands from fans for the popular 1950s badge to be restored, it was decided that the crest should be changed again in 2005. The new crest was officially adopted for the start of the [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06]] season and marked a return to the older design, used from 1953 to 1986, featuring a blue heraldic lion holding a staff. For the centenary season this was accompanied by the words '100 YEARS' and 'CENTENARY 2005–2006' on the top and bottom of the crest respectively.<ref name="new crest"/>
===Colours=== {{Football kit box |align = right |pattern_la = |pattern_b = |pattern_ra = |leftarm = 96C8A2 |body = 96C8A2 |rightarm = 96C8A2 |shorts = FFFFFF |socks = 191970 |title = Chelsea's first home colours, used from 1905 until c. 1912 }}
Chelsea have always worn blue shirts, although they originally used the paler [[eton blue]], which was taken from the racing colours of then club president, [[Earl Cadogan]], and was worn with white shorts and dark blue or black socks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Chelsea/Chelsea.htm |title=Chelsea – Historical Football Kits |work=Historical Kits |accessdate=26 June 2012 }}</ref> The light blue shirts were replaced by a royal blue version in around 1912.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |title=Chelsea Football Club: The Official History in Pictures|year=2006|isbn=978-0-7553-1467-6}} p. 212</ref> In the 1960s Chelsea manager [[Tommy Docherty]] changed the kit again, switching to blue shorts (which have remained ever since) and white socks, believing it made the club's colours more modern and distinctive, since no other major side used that combination; this kit was first worn during the 1964–65 season.<ref>{{cite book |last=Mears |first=Brian |title=Chelsea: Football Under the Blue Flag|publisher=Mainstream Sport|year=2002|isbn=978-1-84018-658-1 |page=42 }}</ref> Since then Chelsea have always worn white socks with their home kit apart from a short spell from 1985 to 1992, when blue socks were reintroduced.
Chelsea's away colours are usually all yellow or all white with blue trim. More recently, the club have had a number of black or dark blue away kits which alternate every year.<ref name="change kits">{{cite web |url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Chelsea/Chelsea-change-kits.html |title=Chelsea Change Kits |work=Historical Kits |accessdate=7 December 2015 }}</ref> As with most teams, they have also had some more unusual ones. At Docherty's behest, in the 1966 FA Cup semi-final they wore blue and black stripes, based on [[Inter Milan]]'s kit.<ref>{{cite book |last=Mears|first=Brian |title=Chelsea: Football Under the Blue Flag|publisher=|year=2002|page=58 }}</ref> In the mid-1970s, the away strip was a red, white and green kit inspired by the [[Golden Team|Hungarian national side]] of the 1950s.<ref>{{cite book |last=Batty |first=Clive|title=Kings of the King's Road: The Great Chelsea Team of the 60s & 70s|publisher=Vision Sports Publishing|year=2007|isbn=978-1-905326-22-8 |page=244}}</ref> Other memorable away kits include an all jade strip worn from 1986–89, red and white diamonds from 1990–92, graphite and tangerine from 1994–96, and luminous yellow from 2007–08.<ref name="change kits"/> The graphite and tangerine strip often appears in lists of the worst football kits ever.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/aug/12/sport.obsmagspecial9|title=Eyes wide shut|work=The Observer|date=12 August 2007|accessdate=7 December 2015}}</ref>
==Support== [[File:Chelsea defend corner.jpg|thumb|250px|Chelsea fans at a match against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], on 11 March 2006]] Chelsea are among the most widely supported football clubs in the world.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/511644/Chelsea-are-a-more-universally-loved-club-Blues-chief-lauds-400million-fan-base |title=Chelsea are a more universally loved club! Blues chief lauds 400million fan base |last=Anderson |first=Jamie |work=Daily Express |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://talksport.com/magazine/big-picture/2011-10-13/worlds-most-popular-football-club-revealed-man-united-liverpool-arsenal-barca-real-or-chelsea|title=The world's most popular football club revealed: Man United, Liverpool F.C., Arsenal F.C., Barca, Real or Chelsea?|work=talkSPORT|date=2011-10-13}}</ref> They have the sixth highest average all-time attendance in [[Football in England|English football]]<ref name="All-time attendance"/> and regularly attract over 40,000 fans to Stamford Bridge; they were the seventh best-supported [[Premier League]] team in the 2013–14 season, with an average gate of 41,572.<ref name="14/15 attendances">{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerstats.com/attendance.asp?league=england|title=Attendances (at home)|publisher=Soccerstats.com|accessdate=21 May 2017}}</ref> Chelsea's traditional fanbase comes from all over the [[Greater London]] area including working-class parts such as [[Hammersmith]] and [[Battersea]], wealthier areas like Chelsea and [[Kensington]], and from the [[home counties]]. There are also numerous official supporters clubs in the United Kingdom and all over the world.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/supporters-clubs |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140323222258/http://www.chelseafc.com/supporters-clubs |archivedate=23 March 2014 |title=Supporters Clubs Map |work=chelseafc.com |accessdate=23 March 2014}}</ref> Between 2007 and 2012, Chelsea were ranked fourth worldwide in annual replica kit sales, with an average of 910,000.<ref>{{cite news |title=EXCLUSIVE: Manchester United and Real Madrid top global shirt sale charts |url=http://www.sportingintelligence.com/2012/10/08/exclusive-manchester-united-and-real-madrid-top-global-shirt-sale-charts-081001/ |work=Sporting Intelligence|date=8 October 2012 |accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref> Chelsea's official Twitter account has 9.8 million followers {{as of|2017|September|lc=y}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://folos.im/|title=League Table of Twitter Followers|work=Folos|accessdate=4 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208081452/http://folos.im/|archive-date=8 December 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
At matches, Chelsea fans sing [[football chants|chants]] such as "[[Carefree (chant)|Carefree]]" (to the tune of "[[Lord of the Dance (hymn)|Lord of the Dance]]", whose lyrics were probably written by supporter Mick Greenaway<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=150}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://fanchants.com/football-songs/chelsea-chants/carefree/ |title="Carefree" audio sample |publisher=Fanchants.com |accessdate=3 September 2011}}</ref>), "Ten Men Went to Mow", "We All Follow the Chelsea" (to the tune of "[[Land of Hope and Glory]]"), "Zigga Zagga", and the celebratory "Celery", with the latter often resulting in fans ritually throwing celery. The vegetable was banned inside Stamford Bridge after an incident involving [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] midfielder [[Cesc Fàbregas]] at the [[2007 Football League Cup Final|2007 League Cup Final]].<ref>{{cite news |date=17 April 2002 |url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,1563,685859,00.html |title=Fans sent spinning after tossing salad |work=The Guardian |accessdate=1 January 2007 |first=Scott |last=Murray}}</ref> During the 1970s and 1980s in particular, Chelsea supporters were associated with [[Football (soccer) hooliganism|football hooliganism]]. The club's "[[Football hooliganism|football firm]]", originally known as the Chelsea Shed Boys, and subsequently as the [[Chelsea Headhunters]], were nationally notorious for football violence, alongside hooligan firms from other clubs such as [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]'s [[Inter City Firm]] and [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]]'s [[Millwall Bushwackers|Bushwackers]], before, during and after matches.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/hooligans/1962503.stm |title=Making a new start |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=21 January 2007 |date=2 May 2002}}</ref> The increase of hooligan incidents in the 1980s led chairman Ken Bates to propose erecting an electric fence to deter them from invading the pitch, a proposal that the [[Greater London Council]] rejected.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/3037508.stm |title=Bates: Chelsea's driving force |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=21 January 2007 |date=2 July 2003}}</ref>
Since the 1990s, there has been a marked decline in crowd trouble at matches, as a result of stricter policing, [[Closed-circuit television|CCTV]] in grounds and the advent of [[All-seater stadium|all-seater stadia]].<ref>{{cite news |date=2 June 1998 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/special_report/1998/hooligans/60146.stm |title=Soccer hooliganism: Made in England, but big abroad |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=1 January 2007}}</ref> In 2007, the club launched the [[Back to the Shed campaign|'Back to the Shed' campaign]] to improve the atmosphere at home matches, with notable success. According to [[Home Office]] statistics, 126 Chelsea fans were arrested for football-related offences during the [[2009–10 in English football|2009–10]] season, the third highest in the division, and 27 [[banning order]]s were issued, the fifth-highest in the division.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/publications/crime/football-arrests-banning-orders/fbo-2009-10?view=Binary |title=Statistics on football-related arrests and banning orders |accessdate=14 May 2011 |date=November 2010 |publisher=Home Office |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317054025/http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/publications/crime/football-arrests-banning-orders/fbo-2009-10?view=Binary |archivedate=17 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Rivalries=== {{Main|West London derby|Arsenal F.C.–Chelsea F.C. rivalry|Chelsea F.C.–Tottenham Hotspur F.C. rivalry|Chelsea F.C.–Leeds United F.C. rivalry}} Chelsea have long-standing rivalries with North London clubs [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=312–318}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/apr/22/a-brief-history-of-the-arsenal-chelsea-rivalry-and-why-it-matters|title=A brief history of the Arsenal-Chelsea rivalry and why it matters|work=The Guardian|date=22 April 2015|accessdate=7 December 2015}}</ref> A [[Chelsea F.C.–Leeds United F.C. rivalry|strong rivalry]] with [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] dates back to several heated and controversial matches in the 1960s and 1970s, particularly the [[1970 FA Cup Final]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=321–325}}</ref> More recently a rivalry with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] has grown following repeated clashes in cup competitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talksport.co.uk/magazine/features/2011-05-19/peterborough-v-mk-dons-liverpool-v-chelsea-stoke-v-cardiff-six-best-modern-football-rivalries|title=Six very modern football rivalries|work=TalkSport|accessdate=23 May 2011|date=19 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/oct/29/chelsea-liverpool-field-notes-rivalry|title=A brief guide to Chelsea's rivalry with Liverpool|work=The Guardian|date=29 October 2015|accessdate=4 December 2015}}</ref> Chelsea's fellow [[West London derby|West London]] sides [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]], [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] are generally not considered major rivals, as matches have only taken place intermittently due to the clubs often being in separate divisions.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=311}}</ref>
A 2004 survey by Planetfootball.com found that Chelsea fans consider their main rivalries to be with (in descending order): [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], Tottenham Hotspur and [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]. In the same survey, fans of Arsenal, Fulham, Leeds United, QPR, Tottenham, and West Ham United named Chelsea as one of their three main rivals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefootballnetwork.net/main/s120/st44186.htm|title=Football Rivalries: The Complete Results|publisher=Planetfootball.com|accessdate=2 January 2007}}</ref> In a 2008 poll conducted by the [[Football Fans Census]], Chelsea fans named Liverpool, Arsenal and Manchester United as their most disliked clubs. In the same survey, "Chelsea" was the top answer to the question "Which other English club do you dislike the most?"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.footballfanscensus.com/londonfootballreport08.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301030022/http://www.footballfanscensus.com/londonfootballreport08.pdf|archivedate=1 March 2014|title=The London Football Report 2008|publisher=Football Fans Census|accessdate=22 May 2018}}</ref>
A 2012 survey, conducted among 1200 supporters of the top four league divisions across the country, found that many clubs' main rivals had changed since 2003 and reported that Chelsea fans consider Tottenham to be their main rival, above Arsenal and Manchester United.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedaisycutter.co.uk/2012/09/football-rivalries-the-survey/|date=14 September 2012|title=Football Rivalries: The Survey|publisher=''The Daisy Cutter''|accessdate=22 May 2018}}</ref>
==Records== {{details|List of Chelsea F.C. records and statistics}} [[File:Frank Lampard'13-14.JPG|thumb|200px|[[Frank Lampard]] is Chelsea's all-time highest goalscorer.]] Chelsea's highest appearance-maker is ex-captain [[Ron Harris (footballer)|Ron Harris]], who played in 795 competitive games for the club between 1961 and 1980.<ref name="stats">For the appearance and goalscoring records of all Chelsea players, see {{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=399–410 }}</ref> The record for a Chelsea goalkeeper is held by Harris's contemporary, [[Peter Bonetti]], who made 729 appearances (1959–79). With 103 [[Cap (sport)|caps]] (101 while at the club), [[Frank Lampard]] of England is Chelsea's most capped international player.
Frank Lampard is Chelsea's all-time top goalscorer, with 211 goals in 648 games (2001–2014);<ref name="stats"/> he passed [[Bobby Tambling]]'s longstanding record of 202 in May 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22589526 |title=Chelsea's Frank Lampard given golden boot by Bobby Tambling |publisher=BBC |date=19 May 2013 |accessdate=7 September 2013 }}</ref> Seven other players have also scored over 100 goals for Chelsea: [[George Hilsdon]] (1906–12), [[George Mills (footballer)|George Mills]] (1929–39), [[Roy Bentley]] (1948–56), [[Jimmy Greaves]] (1957–61), [[Peter Osgood]] (1964–74 and 1978–79), [[Kerry Dixon]] (1983–92) and [[Didier Drogba]] (2004–12 and 2014–2015). Greaves holds the record for the most goals scored in one season (43 in 1960–61).<ref>{{cite web|title=Chelsea Legends|url=http://chelseazone.wordpress.com/chelsea-legends/|publisher=Chelsea News|accessdate=11 August 2014|date=2009-02-17}}</ref>
Chelsea's biggest winning scoreline in a competitive match is 13–0, achieved against [[Jeunesse Hautcharage]] in the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup|Cup Winners' Cup]] in 1971.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2465594|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140423225144/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2465594|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 April 2014|title=Words on Winning: 21–0|website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 April 2014 }}</ref> The club's biggest top-flight win was an 8–0 victory against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] in 2010, which was matched in 2012 against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/matchday-live/match/47531|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140605231009/http://www.chelseafc.com/matchday-live/match/47531|archivedate=5 June 2014|title=Chelsea v Wigan match report |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 April 2014 }}</ref> Chelsea's biggest loss was an 8–1 reverse against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in 1953.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/teamsandplayers/teams/club=52914/profile/index.html|title=Chelsea FC|website=UEFA.com|publisher=Union of European Football Associations|accessdate=15 January 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/chelsea-article/article/3489606/title/ask-statman-37 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131121213128/http://www.chelseafc.com/chelsea-article/article/3489606/title/ask-statman-37 |archivedate=21 November 2013|title=Ask Statsman 37|first=Paul|last=Dutton|publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref> Officially, Chelsea's highest home attendance is 82,905 for a [[Football League First Division|First Division]] match against Arsenal on 12 October 1935. However, an estimated crowd of over 100,000 attended a [[Exhibition game|friendly match]] against Soviet team [[FC Dynamo Moscow|Dynamo Moscow]] on 13 November 1945.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1800268 |title=Team History – 1940s |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713083616/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/TeamHistory/0%2C%2C10268~1800268%2C00.html |archivedate=13 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Brian Viner: Diamond days of side who brought touch of glamour to post-war Britain |first=Brian |last=Viner |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/brian-viner-diamond-days-of-side-who-brought-touch-of-glamour-to-postwar-britain-6143279.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302032913/http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/brian-viner-diamond-days-of-side-who-brought-touch-of-glamour-to-postwar-britain-6143279.html |archivedate=2 March 2014 |work=The Independent |publisher=Independent Print Limited |date=29 October 2005 |accessdate=20 May 2012}}</ref> The modernisation of Stamford Bridge during the 1990s and the introduction of all-seater stands mean that neither record will be broken for the foreseeable future. The current legal capacity of Stamford Bridge is 41,663.<ref name="capacity"/> Every starting player in Chelsea's 57 games of the 2013–14 season was a full international – a new club record.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/08/pre-match-briefing--burnley-v-chelsea.html|title=Pre-Match Briefing: Burnley v Chelsea – part one|publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Fernando Torres 03 Chelsea vs AS-Roma 10AUG2013.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Chelsea signed [[Fernando Torres]] for £50 million, then the record for a purchase by a British club.]] Chelsea hold the English record for the fewest goals conceded during a league season (15), the highest number of clean sheets overall in a Premier League season (25) (both set during the [[2004–05 FA Premier League|2004–05 season]]),<ref name="records">{{cite news |date=13 May 2005|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/4545045.stm|title=Mourinho proud of battling finish |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=29 August 2010}}</ref> and the most consecutive clean sheets from the start of a league season (6, set during the [[2005–06 FA Premier League|2005–06 season]]).<ref>{{cite news|date=17 September 2005|title=Charlton 0–2 Chelsea|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4232354.stm |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=12 November 2007 }}</ref> The club's 21–0 [[Aggregate score|aggregate]] victory over [[UN Käerjéng 97|Jeunesse Hautcharage]] in the [[1971–72 European Cup Winners' Cup|UEFA Cup Winners' Cup in 1971]] remains a record in European competition.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/cwc.html#rec|title=Cup Winners' Cup Trivia|publisher=Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|accessdate=21 January 2007}}</ref> Chelsea hold the record for the longest streak of unbeaten matches at home in the English top flight, which lasted 86 matches from 20 March 2004 to 26 October 2008. They secured the record on 12 August 2007, beating the previous record of 63 matches unbeaten set by Liverpool between 1978 and 1980.<ref>{{cite news|date=12 August 2007|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/6931067.stm|title=Chelsea 3–2 Birmingham |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=9 October 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7674108.stm|title=Chelsea 0–1 Liverpool|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=26 October 2008 |date=26 October 2008}}</ref> Chelsea's streak of eleven consecutive away league wins, set between 5 April 2008 and 6 December 2008, is also a record for the English top flight.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea in eleven heaven |url=http://www.premierleague.com/page/Magazinedettail/0,,12306~1491763,00.html |publisher=Premier League |date=8 December 2008 |accessdate=18 January 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219192857/http://www.premierleague.com/page/Magazinedettail/0%2C%2C12306~1491763%2C00.html |archivedate=19 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Their £50 million purchase of [[Fernando Torres]] from Liverpool in January 2011 was the [[Progression of British football transfer fee record|record transfer fee paid by a British club]]<ref>{{cite news|date=31 January 2011 |title=Torres makes record move from Liverpool to Chelsea|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/9380389.stm |publisher=BBC|accessdate=12 March 2012 }}</ref> until [[Ángel Di María]] signed for Manchester United in August 2014 for £59.7 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/12691/9441613/transfer-news-manchester-united-complete-signing-of-angel-di-maria.html |title=Transfer news: Manchester United sign Angel di Maria from Real Madrid |work=Sky Sports }}</ref>
Chelsea, along with Arsenal, were the first club to play with shirt numbers, on 25 August 1928 in their match against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea Town]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/TeamUnif/UnifNosNames.html|title=Shirt Numbers |work=England Football Online|accessdate=1 October 2006 }}</ref> They were the first English side to travel by aeroplane to a domestic away match, when they visited [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on 19 April 1957,<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=96}}</ref> and the first First Division side to play a match on a Sunday, when they faced [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on 27 January 1974. On 26 December 1999, Chelsea became the first British side to field an entirely foreign [[starting line-up]] (no British or Irish players) in a Premier League match against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite news |date=27 December 1999 |url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/chelsea/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/99/12/26/SOCCER_Southampton_Nightlead.html&TEAMHD=chelsea&DIV=prem&TEAM=CHELSEA&RH=Chelsea&PREV_SEASON=1998 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603160304/http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/chelsea/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer%2F99%2F12%2F26%2FSOCCER_Southampton_Nightlead.html&TEAMHD=chelsea&DIV=prem&TEAM=CHELSEA&RH=Chelsea&PREV_SEASON=1998 |archivedate=3 June 2012 |title=Southampton 1 Chelsea 2 |work=Sporting Life |accessdate=27 January 2007 |last=Bradley |first=Mark |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
In May 2007, Chelsea were the first team to win the FA Cup at the new [[Wembley Stadium]], having also been the last to win it at the old Wembley.<ref>{{cite news|date=20 May 2007|title=Something old, new and Blue|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2007/may/19/somethingoldnewandblue |work=The Observer|accessdate=14 July 2011|last=Mitchell |first=Kevin}}</ref> They were the first English club to be ranked No. 1 under [[UEFA coefficient|UEFA's five-year coefficient]] system in the 21st century.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.xs4all.nl/~kassiesa/bert/uefa/data/method3/trank2008.html|title=UEFA Team Ranking 2008 |work=UEFA European Cup Football: Results and Qualification|last=Kassies |first=Bert|accessdate=2 June 2008 }}</ref> They were the first team in Premier League history, and the first team in the English top flight since their great rivals Tottenham Hotspur in 1962–63, to score at least 100 goals in a single season, reaching the milestone on the final day of the 2009–10 season.<ref name=Wigan80/> Chelsea are the only London club to win the [[UEFA Champions League]], after beating Bayern Munich in the [[2012 UEFA Champions League Final|2012 final]].<ref name="Chelsea win breaks London duck"/><ref name="Chelsea etch new name on trophy">{{cite news |title=Chelsea etch new name on trophy |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=1798280.html#chelsea+etch+name+trophy |work=Union of European Football Associations |date=19 May 2012 |accessdate=20 May 2012 }}</ref> Upon winning the [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League]], Chelsea became the first English club to [[European football records|win all four European trophies]] and the only club to hold the Champions League and the Europa League at the same time.<ref>{{cite news|date=15 May 2013|title=Chelsea first team to hold Champions, Europa League titles |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2013/05/chelsea-first-team-to-hold-champions-europa-league-titles/ |work=Vanguard}}</ref>
==Ownership and finances== [[File:Roman Abramovich 2.jpg|thumb|200px|Chelsea owner [[Roman Abramovich]]]] Chelsea Football Club were founded by [[Gus Mears]] in 1905. After his death in 1912, his descendants continued to own the club until 1982, when [[Ken Bates]] bought the club from Mears' great-nephew [[Brian Mears]] for £1. Bates bought a controlling stake in the club and floated Chelsea on the [[Alternative Investment Market|AIM]] stock exchange in March 1996.<ref>{{cite web |title=UK Football Clubs on the UK Stock Markets |url=http://www.footballeconomy.com/stats/stats_turnover_09.htm |publisher=Football Economy |accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> In July 2003, [[Roman Abramovich]] purchased just over 50% of Chelsea Village plc's share capital, including Bates' 29.5% stake, for £30 million and over the following weeks bought out most of the remaining 12,000 shareholders at 35 pence per share, completing a £140 million takeover. Other shareholders at the time of the takeover included the [[Matthew Harding]] estate (21%), [[BSkyB]] (9.9%) and various anonymous offshore trusts.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bates sells off Chelsea to a Russian billionaire |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2406994/Bates-sells-off-Chelsea-to-a-Russian-billionaire.html |work=The Daily Telegraph|date=7 February 2003 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> After passing the 90% share threshold, Abramovich took the club back into private hands, delisting it from the AIM on 22 August 2003. He also took on responsibility for the club's debt of £80 million, quickly paying most of it.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea tycoon to clear club's debt |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3102819.stm |publisher=BBC|date=28 July 2003 |accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref>
Thereafter, Abramovich changed the ownership name to Chelsea FC plc, whose ultimate parent company is Fordstam Limited, which is controlled by him.<ref>{{cite web|title=Club Information |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/page/ClubInfo/0,,10268,00.html? |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702215947/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/ClubInfo/0%2C%2C10268%2C00.html |archivedate=2 July 2012 |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=26 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Chelsea are additionally funded by Abramovich via interest free [[soft loan]]s channelled through his holding company Fordstam Limited. The loans stood at £709 million in December 2009, when they were all converted to [[Equity (finance)|equity]] by Abramovich, leaving the club themselves debt free,<ref>{{cite news |title=Roman Abramovich turns £340m of debt into equity as Chelsea loss falls |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/dec/30/roman-abramovich-chelsea-debts-accounts |work=The Guardian|date=30 December 2009 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Statement on Club Finance|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2055740 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140423225239/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2055740 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 April 2014 |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref> although the debt remains with Fordstam.<ref>{{cite news |title=Roman Abramovich still owed £726m under complex Chelsea structure |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/may/19/roman-abramovich-chelsea-loan-debt |work=The Guardian|date=19 May 2010 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> Since 2008 the club have had no external debt.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea and United debts at record £1.5bn |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/may/20/premierleague.chelsea |work=The Guardian|date=20 May 2008 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref>
Chelsea did not turn a profit in the first nine years of Abramovich's ownership, and made record losses of £140m in June 2005.<ref name="first profit">{{cite news |title=Chelsea FC record first Abramovich-era profit|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/20270934 |publisher=BBC|date=9 November 2012 |accessdate=25 February 2015}}</ref> In November 2012, Chelsea announced a profit of £1.4 million for the year ending 30 June 2012, the first time the club had made a profit under Abramovich's ownership.<ref name="first profit"/><ref>{{cite news |title=CHELSEA FC ANNOUNCES ANNUAL PROFIT |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2975285/title/chelsea-fc-announces-annual-profit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111072755/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2975285/title/chelsea-fc-announces-annual-profit |archivedate=11 November 2012 |publisher=Chelsea FC|date=9 November 2012 |accessdate=9 November 2012}}</ref> This was followed by a loss in 2013 and then their highest ever profit of £18.4 million for the year to June 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea FC reports a record £18m in annual profit|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-30045978|accessdate=14 November 2014|publisher=BBC|date=14 November 2014}}</ref>
Chelsea have been described as a global brand; a 2012 report by [[Brand Finance]] ranked Chelsea fifth among football brands and valued the club's brand value at US$398 million – an increase of 27% from the previous year, also valuing them at US$10 million more than the sixth best brand, London rivals Arsenal – and gave the brand a strength rating of AA (very strong).<ref>{{cite web |title=Top 20 most Valuable Football Club Brands |url=http://www.brandfinance.com/images/upload/top_30_european_football_brands_2011_final_website.pdf |publisher=Brand Finance |accessdate=26 June 2012 |date=May 2012 |format=PDF }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Top 30 Football Club Brands |url=http://www.brandfinance.com/images/upload/brandfinance_football_brands_2012.pdf |publisher=Brand Finance |accessdate=4 October 2011 |date=September 2011 |format=PDF }}</ref> In 2016, ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine ranked Chelsea the seventh most valuable football club in the world, at £1.15 billion ($1.66 billion).<ref name="Forbes Valuation">{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikeozanian/2017/06/06/the-worlds-most-valuable-soccer-teams-2017/#54c9255a77ea|title=The World's Most Valuable Soccer Teams 2017|last1=Ozanian|first1=Mike|date=6 June 2017|website=Forbes|accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> {{as of|2016}}, Chelsea are ranked eighth in the [[Deloitte Football Money League]] with an annual commercial revenue of £322.59 million.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea – Deloitte Football Money League|url=http://www2.deloitte.com/uk/en/pages/sports-business-group/articles/deloitte-football-money-league.html |work=Deloitte |accessdate=21 January 2016 }}</ref>
===Sponsorship=== [[File:Sergio Perez 2012 Canadian GP - Crop.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Sauber|Sauber F1 Team]], an official partner of the club, displaying the Chelsea crest]] Chelsea's kit has been manufactured by [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] since July 2017. Previously, the kit was manufactured by [[Adidas]], which was originally contracted to supply the club's kit from 2006 to 2018. The partnership was extended in October 2010 in a deal worth £160 million over eight years.<ref>{{cite news |date=22 October 2010 |title=Chelsea manager Carlo Ancelotti puts his faith in elder statesman Didier Drogba |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/8081823/Chelsea-manager-Carlo-Ancelotti-puts-his-faith-in-elder-statesman-Didier-Drogba.html |work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> This deal was again extended in June 2013 in a deal worth £300 million over another ten years.<ref>{{cite news |date=22 June 2013 |title=Chelsea agree whopping £300m kit deal with sportswear giants adidas |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2346083/Chelsea-agree-record-300m-kit-deal-sportswear-giants-adidas.html |work=Daily Mail |location=London |accessdate=22 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=22 June 2013 |title=Chelsea and Adidas Announce Extension of Global Partnership |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/3216081/title/chelsea-and-adidas-announce-extension-of-global-partnership |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624022143/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/3216081/title/chelsea-and-adidas-announce-extension-of-global-partnership |archivedate=24 June 2013 |publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=22 June 2013}}</ref> In May 2016, Adidas announced that by mutual agreement, the kit sponsorship would end six years early on 30 June 2017.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-36266181 |title=Adidas ends Chelsea sponsorship six years early |date=11 May 2016 |publisher=BBC |access-date=28 December 2016}}</ref> Chelsea had to pay £40m in compensation to Adidas. In October 2016, Nike was announced as the new kit sponsor, in a deal worth £900m over 15 years, until 2032.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/oct/13/chelsea-new-kit-deal-nike-60m |title=Chelsea confirm kit deal with Nike worth £60m a season until 2032 |date=13 October 2016 |work=The Guardian |access-date=28 December 2016}}</ref> Previously, the kit was manufactured by [[Umbro]] (1975–81), [[Le Coq Sportif]] (1981–86), The Chelsea Collection (1986–87), Umbro (1987–2006), and Adidas (2006–2017).
Chelsea's first shirt sponsor was [[Gulf Air]], agreed during the 1983–84 season. The club were then sponsored by Grange Farms, [[Peter Foster|Bai Lin Tea]] and [[Simod]] before a long-term deal was signed with [[Commodore International]] in 1989; [[Amiga]], an offshoot of Commodore, also appeared on the shirts. Chelsea were subsequently sponsored by [[Coors Brewing Company|Coors]] beer (1994–97), [[Autoglass]] (1997–2001), [[Emirates (airline)|Emirates]] (2001–05), [[Samsung Mobile]] (2005–08) and [[Samsung Group|Samsung]] (2008–15).<ref name=yokohama/><ref>{{cite news |date=2 May 2005 |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article387503.ece|title=Clubs to cash in on mobile advertising |work=The Times |location=UK |accessdate=21 January 2010 |first=Ashling |last=O'Connor}}</ref> Chelsea's current shirt sponsor is the [[Yokohama Rubber Company]]. Worth £40 million per year, the deal is second in English football to [[Chevrolet]]'s £50 million-per-year sponsorship of Manchester United.<ref name=yokohama>{{cite news|title=Chelsea sign £40m-per-year shirt deal with Japanese tyre company|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31653343|accessdate=27 February 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 February 2015}}</ref>
Following the door-opening of sleeve sponsor in the English League, Chelsea had [[Alliance Tire Company|Alliance Tyres]] as its first sleeve sponsor in the [[2017–18 Chelsea F.C. season|2017–18 season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/07/alliance-tyres-to-appear-on-2017-18-sleeves.html |title=Alliance Tyres to appear on 2017/18 sleeves |website=chelseafc.com |accessdate=22 July 2017|date=22 July 2017}}</ref> For the [[2018–19 Chelsea F.C. season|2018–19 season]], they have [[Hyundai Motor Company]] as the new sleeve sponsor.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2018/6/11/chelsea-and-hyundai-begin-new-partnership |title=Chelsea and Hyundai Begin New Partnership |website=chelseafc.com |accessdate=11 June 2018|date=11 June 2018}}</ref>
The club has a variety of other sponsors, which include [[Carabao Energy Drink|Carabao]], [[Delta Air Lines]], [[Beats by Dre]], [[Singha]], [[EA Sports]], [[Rexona]], [[Hublot]], [[Ericsson]], [[William Hill (bookmaker)|William Hill]], [[Levy Restaurants]], [[Wipro]], [[International Beverages Trading|Grand Royal Whisky]], [[Bangkok Bank]], [[Guangzhou R&F F.C.|Guangzhou R&F]], [[Mobinil]], [[IndusInd Bank]], and Ole777.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/the-club/sponsors.html|title=Sponsors and Partners |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=4 November 2014}}</ref>
==Popular culture== [[File:Chelsea double winner 2009-10.JPG|left|thumb|200px|Chelsea parade through the streets of Fulham and Chelsea after winning their league and cup double, May 2010]] In 1930, Chelsea featured in one of the earliest football films, ''[[The Great Game (1930 film)|The Great Game]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0020936/ |title=The Great Game |publisher=Internet Movie Database |accessdate=1 October 2007 }}</ref> One-time Chelsea centre forward, [[Jack Cock]], who by then was playing for [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]], was the star of the film and several scenes were shot at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], including on the pitch, the boardroom, and the [[dressing room]]s. It included guest appearances by then-Chelsea players [[Andrew Nesbit Wilson|Andrew Wilson]], [[George Mills (footballer)|George Mills]], and [[Sam Millington]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=120–121}}</ref> Owing to the notoriety of the [[Chelsea Headhunters]], a [[football firm]] associated with the club, Chelsea have also featured in films about football [[hooliganism]], including 2004's ''[[The Football Factory (film)|The Football Factory]]''.<ref>{{cite news |date=10 May 2004 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/film/3687227.stm |title=Football firms hit the film circuit |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=25 January 2007 |first=Steve |last=Hawkes}}</ref> Chelsea also appear in the [[Hindi]] film ''[[Jhoom Barabar Jhoom]]''.<ref>{{cite news |date=25 September 2006 |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/report.asp?NewsID=1055099 |title=Chelsea teams up with Yash Raj Films |publisher=DNA India |accessdate=1 January 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930015215/http://www.dnaindia.com/report.asp?NewsID=1055099 |archivedate=30 September 2007 }}</ref> In April 2011, [[Montenegro|Montenegrin]] comedy series ''Nijesmo mi od juče'' made an episode in which Chelsea play against [[FK Sutjeska Nikšić]] for qualification of the [[UEFA Champions League]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nijesmomiodjuce.com/nijesmo-mi-od-juce-novosti/epizoda-chelsea-u-gledajte-onlajn-sekciji/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130830104319/http://www.nijesmomiodjuce.com/nijesmo-mi-od-juce-novosti/epizoda-chelsea-u-gledajte-onlajn-sekciji/|archivedate=30 August 2013|title=Nijesmo mi od Juce – Novosti – Epizode – Chelsea u "gledajte onlajn" sekciji|publisher=nijesmomiodjuce.com|accessdate=23 April 2014|language=Montenegrin}}</ref>
Up until the 1950s, the club had a long-running association with the [[music hall]]s; their underachievement often provided material for comedians such as [[George Robey]].<ref>{{cite news |date=30 September 2002 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2002/sep/30/match.sport7 |title=Di Canio has last laugh at Chelsea comedy store |work=The Guardian |accessdate=14 July 2011 |first=Scott |last=Murray}}</ref> It culminated in comedian Norman Long's release of a [[Novelty song|comic song]] in 1933, ironically titled "On the Day That Chelsea Went and Won the Cup", the lyrics of which describe a series of bizarre and improbable occurrences on the hypothetical day when Chelsea finally won a trophy.<ref name="glanville"/> In [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s 1935 film ''[[The 39 Steps (1935 film)|The 39 Steps]]'', Mr Memory claims that Chelsea last won the Cup in 63 BC, "in the presence of the [[List of Roman emperors|Emperor]] [[Nero]]."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0026029/quotes |title=The 39 Steps |publisher=Internet Movie Database |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref> Scenes in a 1980 episode of ''[[Minder (TV series)|Minder]]'' were filmed during a real match at Stamford Bridge between Chelsea and [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] with Terry McCann (played by [[Dennis Waterman]]) standing on the terraces.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.minder.org/episodeguide/S02E12_AllAboutScoringInnit.htm |title=All About Scoring, Innit? |publisher=Minder.org |accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref>
The song "[[Blue Is the Colour (song)|Blue is the Colour]]" was released as a single in the build-up to the [[1972 Football League Cup Final|1972 League Cup Final]], with all members of Chelsea's first team squad singing; it reached number five in the [[UK Singles Chart]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chartstats.com/songinfo.php?id=5791 |title=Blue Is The Colour |work=Chart Stats |accessdate=21 January 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120128094321/http://www.chartstats.com/songinfo.php?id=5791 |archivedate=28 January 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> The song has since been adopted as an anthem by a number of other sports teams around the world, including the [[Vancouver Whitecaps (1986–2010)|Vancouver Whitecaps]] (as "White is the Colour")<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vancourier.com/issues02/045202/sports.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103163706/http://www.vancourier.com/issues02/045202/sports.html |archivedate=3 January 2008 |title=Caps' 'Proclaim' season opener |work=Vancouver Courier |accessdate=21 January 2007}}</ref> and the [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]] (as "Green is the Colour").<ref>{{cite news |date=26 November 2009 |url=http://www2.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/city/story.html?id=2a537f58-d315-495f-8ba5-0359dd597ed9 |title=Riders fans enjoy musical edge |work=Calgary Herald |accessdate=5 May 2014 |first=Stephen |last=Hunt |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505195145/http://www2.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/city/story.html?id=2a537f58-d315-495f-8ba5-0359dd597ed9 |archivedate=5 May 2014 }}</ref> In the build-up to the [[1997 FA Cup Final]], the song "Blue Day", performed by [[Suggs (singer)|Suggs]] and members of the Chelsea squad, reached number 22 in the UK charts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chartstats.com/songinfo.php?id=25206 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070930013126/http://www.chartstats.com/songinfo.php?id=25206 |archivedate=30 September 2007 |title=Blue Day |work=Chart Stats |accessdate=11 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> {{clear}}
==Chelsea Women== {{details|Chelsea F.C. Women}}<!-- NOTE: Please make detailed additions to the [[Chelsea F.C. Women]] article -->
Chelsea also operate a [[Women's association football|women's football]] team, [[Chelsea L.F.C.|Chelsea Football Club Women]], formerly known as Chelsea Ladies. They have been affiliated to the men's team since 2004<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.femalesoccer.net/show_news_article.php?id=3523|title=Chelsea Moving on Up|publisher=FemaleSoccer.net|accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref> and are part of the club's Community Development programme. They play their home games at [[Kingsmeadow]], the home ground of the [[EFL League One]] club [[AFC Wimbledon]]. The club were promoted to the [[FA Women's Premier League National Division|Premier Division]] for the first time in 2005 as [[FA Women's Premier League Southern Division|Southern Division]] champions and won the Surrey County Cup nine times between 2003 and 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.surreyfa.com/previous-winners-and-officials/womens-cup-previous-winners |title=Womens Cup Previous Winners |publisher=surreyfa.com |accessdate=11 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140905005953/https://www.surreyfa.com/previous-winners-and-officials/womens-cup-previous-winners |archivedate=5 September 2014 }}</ref> In 2010 Chelsea Ladies were one of the eight founder members of the [[FA Women's Super League]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fcbusiness.co.uk/news/article/newsitem=195/title=eight+teams+successful+in+women%26%23039%3Bs+super+league+bid|title=Eight teams successful in Women's Super League bid|publisher=fcbusiness.co.uk|accessdate=20 February 2011|location=London|date=24 March 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110125233233/http://fcbusiness.co.uk/news/article/newsitem%3D195/title%3Deight+teams+successful+in+women%26%23039%3Bs+super+league+bid|archivedate=25 January 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2015, Chelsea Ladies won the [[2014–15 FA Women's Cup|FA Women's Cup]] for the first time, beating [[Notts County Ladies F.C.|Notts County Ladies]] at [[Wembley Stadium]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://shekicks.net/news/view/12007 |title=Chelsea lift FA Cup in front of record crowd |publisher=shekicks.net |date=2 August 2015 |accessdate=2 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208081036/http://shekicks.net/news/view/12007 |archivedate=8 December 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and a month later clinched their first [[FA WSL]] title to complete a league and cup double.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34336364|title=Chelsea Ladies: How Women's Super League title was won|publisher=BBC |location=UK |accessdate=30 November 2015 |date=5 October 2015}}</ref> [[John Terry]], former captain of the Chelsea men's team, is the President of Chelsea Women.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/oct/18/john-terry-chelsea-womens-football|title=John Terry digs deep to rescue Chelsea Ladies after funding cuts|work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=20 February 2011 |first=Tony |last=Leighton |date=18 October 2009}}</ref>

==Club personnel== Chelsea FC plc is the company which owns Chelsea Football Club. The ultimate parent company of Chelsea FC plc is Fordstam Limited and the ultimate controlling party of Fordstam Limited is [[Roman Abramovich]].<ref name="Club Personnel">{{cite web|title=Club Personnel|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/about-chelsea/about-the-club/club-personnel|publisher=Chelsea FC|date=18 July 2018}}</ref>
On 22 October 2014, Chelsea announced that [[Ron Gourlay]], after ten successful years at the club including five as Chief Executive, is leaving Chelsea to pursue new business opportunities.<ref>{{cite web|title=Club statement|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/10/club-statement.html|publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=22 October 2014|date=22 October 2014}}</ref> On 27 October 2014, Chelsea announced that [[Christian Purslow]] is joining the club to run global commercial activities and the club do not expect to announce any other senior appointments in the near future having chairman [[Bruce Buck]] and Director [[Marina Granovskaia]] assumed the executive responsibilities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/10/chelsea-statement.html|title=Chelsea Statement|publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=27 October 2014|date=27 October 2014}}</ref> [[Guy Laurence]] was appointed as the club's Chief Executive on 11 January 2018, filling the vacancy following the departure of [[Michael Emenalo]].<ref name=GuyLaurence>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2018/01/new-chief-executive-appointed.html|title=New Chief Executive Appointed|publisher=Chelsea Football Club|date=11 January 2018}}</ref>

==Honours== {{Main|List of Chelsea F.C. records and statistics#Honours and achievements}} Upon winning the [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League]], Chelsea became the fourth club in history to have won the "[[UEFA club competition records and statistics#List of teams to have won the three main European club competitions|European Treble]]" of [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup/UEFA Champions League]], [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup/UEFA Europa League]], and [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup|European Cup Winners' Cup/UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] after [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] and [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]. Chelsea are the first English club to have won all three major UEFA trophies.<ref>{{cite news|date=15 May 2013|title=Chelsea join illustrious trio |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=1947872.html |publisher=UEFA}}</ref>
