web|url=http://www.skysports.com/leicester-city-stats |title=Leicester city stats |publisher=Skysports.com |accessdate=17 May 2016}}}} However, on 30 June 2015, Pearson was sacked, with the club stating, "[T]he working relationship between Nigel and the Board is no longer viable." The sacking was linked to a number of [[public relations]] issues involving Pearson throughout the season, with the final straw involving his son [[James Pearson (footballer, born 1993)|James]]' role in a "racist sex tape" made by three Leicester reserve players in Thailand during a post-season goodwill tour.{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33339566 | title=Nigel Pearson: Leicester boss's sacking linked to son's actions | publisher=BBC Sport | date=1 July 2015 | accessdate=1 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/leicester-city-parts-company-with-nigel-pearson-2515428.aspx|title=Leicester City parts company with Nigel Pearson|publisher=Leicester City FC|date=30 June 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33338638|title=Nigel Pearson: Leicester City sack manager|publisher=BBC|date=30 June 2015}} Leicester reacted by appointing former Chelsea manager [[Claudio Ranieri]] as their new manager for the new [[2015–16 Premier League|2015–16 Premier League season]].{{cite web|title=Claudio Ranieri: Leicester City appoint ex-Chelsea manager|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33513290|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 July 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015}} Under Ranieri, the club made an exceptional start to the season. Striker [[Jamie Vardy]] scored 13 goals over 11 consecutive matches from August to November, breaking [[Ruud van Nistelrooy]]'s Premier League record of scoring in 10 consecutive matches.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34953098 |title=Jamie Vardy breaks record for goals in consecutive games |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=28 November 2015 |accessdate=4 May 2016}} On 19 December, Leicester defeated Everton 3–2 at [[Goodison Park]] to top the Premier League on Christmas Day, having been bottom exactly 12 months earlier.{{cite web|last=Osborne |first=Chris |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35078549 |title=Everton 2–3 Leicester City |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=19 December 2015 |accessdate=4 May 2016}} A 2–0 victory at Sunderland on 10 April, coupled with Tottenham Hotspur's 3–0 win over Manchester United, ensured Leicester's qualification for the [[UEFA Champions League]] for the first time in their history.{{cite news|last1=Clark|first1=Gill|title=Leicester qualify for Champions League|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2896/premier-league/2016/04/10/22223602/leicester-qualify-for-champions-league|accessdate=10 April 2016|work=Goal.com|ref=CL qual}} Leicester won the Premier League on 2 May 2016 after Tottenham threw away a 2–0 lead against Chelsea, drawing 2–2 at the "Battle of [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]]".{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/35988673|title=Leicester City win Premier League title after Tottenham draw at Chelsea|author=|date=2 May 2016|accessdate=2 May 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Lawrence|first1=Amy|title=Leicester celebrate first title after Chelsea recover for Tottenham draw|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/02/chelsea-tottenham-hotspur-premier-league-match-report|accessdate=2 May 2016|work=The Guardian}} This completed the fastest seven-year rise to the title except for Ipswich Town in 1962, and Leicester faced a far more unequal top tier than Ipswich did back then.{{cite web|last1=Curley|first1=James|last2=Roeder|first2=Oliver|title=English Soccer's Mysterious Worldwide Popularity – Contexts|url=https://contexts.org/articles/english-soccers-mysterious-worldwide-popularity/|website=contexts.org|accessdate=7 May 2016}} [[Bookmaker]]s thought Leicester's victory was so unlikely that [[Ladbrokes]] and [[William Hill (bookmaker)|William Hill]] offered odds of 5,000–1 for it at the start of the season. Neither bookmaker had ever paid out such long odds, and the trophy resulted in the largest payout in British sporting history with total winnings of £25 million.{{cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/central/2016-05-02/bookies-set-to-hand-over-15m-if-leicester-win-title/|title=Bookies set to hand over £15m if Leicester win title|publisher=ITV News|date=2 May 2016|accessdate=3 May 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Rayner|first1=Gordon|last2=Brown|first2=Oliver|title=Leicester City win Premier League and cost bookies biggest ever payout|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/02/leicester-city-win-premier-league-and-cost-bookies-biggest-ever/|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=2 May 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Wood|first1=Greg|title=The 5,000-1 payouts on Leicester only tell part of Premier League betting story|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/03/5000-1-outsider-leicester-city-bookmakers|accessdate=6 May 2016|work=The Guardian|date=3 May 2016}} The scale of the surprise attracted global attention for the club and the city of Leicester.{{cite news|last1=Hinshelwood|first1=Colin|title=Thailand Cheers as Far-away Leicester City Clinches Unlikely Soccer Title|url=http://time.com/4314711/leicester-city-chelsea-football-club-tottenham-hotspur-fc/|work=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|accessdate=2 May 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Granados|first1=Nelson|title=Leicester City Wins English Premier League And Takes Over Social Media|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/nelsongranados/2016/05/03/leicester-city-wins-english-premier-league-and-takes-over-social-media/|website=Forbes|accessdate=7 May 2016}} ''[[The Economist]]'' declared it would be "pored over for management lessons".{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/business-and-finance/21698059-leicester-city-management-lessons |title=The success of Leicester City will be pored over for management lessons |work=The Economist| date=7 May 2016 |accessdate=4 May 2016}} Several commentators have viewed it as an inspiration to other clubs and fundamentally transforming the expectations similar sized clubs face in English football.{{cite news|last1=Sharma|first1=Aabhas|title=Leicester City: The champions who were never meant to be|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/opinion/leicester-city-the-champions-who-were-never-meant-to-be-116050300434_1.html|accessdate=3 May 2016|date=3 May 2016}} Ranieri himself viewed the achievement as not the greatest of the Football League, reserving instead that honour to Brian Cough's Nottingham Forest, another provincial club that had won the English First Division two years in succession over the seasons 1977-79, and who went on to win the European cup in the 1977-79 season.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37063137|title=leicesters-achievement-not-as-great-as-cloughs-forest|publisher=Goal|}} Leicester became known for their counterattacking style of play, "incredible pace in the areas it is most essential" and defensive solidarity.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/12/21/return-4-4-2-non-striking-strikers-keepers-can-play-tactical/|title=The return of 4–4–2, non-striking strikers and keepers who can play: The tactical trends of 2016|author=JJ Bull|date=21 December 2016|accessdate=21 December 2016}} Former boss [[Nigel Pearson]] was credited by several pundits and fans as having laid the foundations for Leicester's title winning season.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/09/leicester-city-fans-verdict-nigel-pearson-claudio-ranieri|title=Nigel Pearson verdict|author=Chris Whiting|date=9 May 2016|accessdate=9 May 2016}} Players were often praised for their work ethic and togetherness which was apparent throughout the squad. Reacting to City winning the Premier League, Executive chairman [[Richard Scudamore]] said: {{cquote|If this was a once in every 5,000-year event, then we've effectively got another 5,000 years of hope ahead of us.}} A film has been planned of the story, centred on Jamie Vardy.{{cite news|last1=Hyde|first1=Marina|title=What will Hollywood make of Leicester's spellbinding season?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/04/jamie-vardy-leicester-hollywood-louis-tomlinson-vinnie-jones-premier-league-movie|accessdate=7 May 2016|work=The Guardian|date=4 May 2016}} ===Established Premier League side (2016–present)=== Just ahead of the opening match of the [[2016–17 Leicester City F.C. season|2016–17 season]], Ranieri cautioned against excessive hope of City retaining the title arguing that the other clubs now understood Leicester's break tactics. His principal objective, as last season, was to avoid relegation. He also warned against overconfidence against relegation favourites – by implication, their next opponents, newly promoted Hull City.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/aug/11/claudio-ranieri-more-chance-et-landing-leicester-title|title=Claudio Ranieri: more chance of ET landing than Leicester retaining title|author=Paul MacInnes|work=Guardian newspapers|date=11 August 2016|accessdate=11 August 2016}} His view on Leicester's chances were shared by Gary Lineker, who said that [[N'Golo Kanté]], who left the club during the summer to join Chelsea, had been Leicester's most important player and essential to Ranieri's system.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37063137|title=Gary Lineker: Leicester City will not win title after N'Golo Kante exit|publisher=BBC Sport|date=12 August 2016|accessdate=12 August 2016}} Leicester initially struggled in their domestic form during 2016–17, spending much of the first few months in the bottom half of the table. In December 2016, Ranieri was awarded [[BBC Sports Personality of the Year Coach Award|coach of the year]] and Leicester [[BBC Sports Personality Team of the Year Award|team of the year]] at the [[BBC Sports Personality of the Year]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37063137|title=Sports Personality 2016: Leicester win Team of the Year, Claudio Ranieri top coach|publisher=BBC Sport|date=20 December 2016|accessdate=20 December 2016}} However, on 23 February 2017, Ranieri was sacked due to the club's continuing poor form, resulting in them being only one point above the relegation zone. Gary Lineker called the sacking "very sad" and "inexplicable",{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39072867|title=Claudio Ranieri: Leicester manager sacking made Gary Lineker 'shed a tear'|date=24 February 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}} while Manchester United manager [[José Mourinho]] blamed it on "selfish players". Rumours began emerging some days later that players had been meeting with the owners to discuss Ranieri's sacking without Ranieri knowing, which sparked widespread outrage over social media.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/gossip|title=Football transfer gossip: Barkley, Vermaelen, Mahrez, Neymar, Sanchez|publisher=BBC Sport}} Commenting on the collapse in form of the team and particularly Jamie Vardy during the first 20 matches of the 2016–17 season, [[Alan Shearer]] said Vardy had signed a "bumper new contract", but was no longer doing what brought him success last season, and that the entire club was "no longer doing the basics".{{cite news|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/alan-shearer-leicester-city-s-jamie-vardy-has-had-his-head-turned-by-success/story-30093574-detail/story.html|title=Alan Shearer: Leicester City's Jamie Vardy has 'had his head turned by success'|author=DanielJBird|work=Leicester Mercury|date=28 January 2017|accessdate=4 February 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170128120837/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/alan-shearer-leicester-city-s-jamie-vardy-has-had-his-head-turned-by-success/story-30093574-detail/story.html|archivedate=28 January 2017}} Less than a week after Ranieri was sacked, [[Craig Shakespeare]] took over as caretaker manager, and in his first match in charge, Leicester won 3–1 against fifth-placed Liverpool, with Vardy scoring a brace.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39024318|title=Leicester City 3–1 Liverpool|date=27 February 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}} In his second match as caretaker, Shakespeare led Leicester to another 3–1 victory, over Hull City.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39086672|title=Leicester City 3–1 Hull City|date=4 March 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}} Following two impressive results and initiating "the type of positive response that we hoped change would bring", the club's owners then decided Shakespeare would become the club's manager until the end of the season.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/2016-17/craig-shakespeare-lcfc-interim-manager-takes-charge-until-the-end-of-the-season-3619260.aspx|title=Craig Shakespeare Takes Charge of Leicester City Until The end of the Season|publisher=Leicester City F.C.|date=12 March 2017}} The 2016–17 campaign was also the first season in 15 years that Leicester qualified for European football. Leicester were placed in [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League group stage#Group G|Group G]] of the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League]], alongside [[FC Porto|Porto]], [[F.C. Copenhagen|Copenhagen]] and [[Club Brugge KV|Club Brugge]]. In their inaugural Champions League campaign, they went undefeated in their first five matches to progress to the knockout stages as group winners.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3964590/Leicester-City-look-limp-Premier-League-brilliant-Champions-League-s-caused-flaky-form-here.html|title=Leicester City look limp in the Premier League but brilliant in the Champions League... so what's caused their flaky form and where do they go from here?|work=Daily Mail|date=23 November 2016|accessdate=20 December 2016}} ''The Foxes'' then faced [[La Liga]] club [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] in the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League knockout phase#Round of 16|round of 16]] and defeated the Spanish side 2–0 on the night, and 3–2 on aggregate to advance to the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League knockout phase#Quarter-finals|quarter-finals]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39275115|title=Leicester reach Champions League quarter-finals and threaten to defy logic again|date=15 March 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}} There they faced [[Atlético Madrid]], and drew 1–1 in the second leg, but lost 1–2 on aggregate after losing 1–0 in the first leg. This put an end to Leicester's 2016–17 European campaign, as they finished as Champions League quarter-finalists.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39611647|title=Leicester City 1–1 Atlético Madrid|date=18 April 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}} Despite the loss, Leicester remained unbeaten at home in the 2016–17 Champions League campaign. Commenting on the first match of Leicester's [[2017–18 Leicester City F.C. season|2017–18 season]], a close-fought 4–3 loss to Arsenal, ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper reported that Vardy was extremely well-suited to the current Leicester team – the "embodiment of pure Leicester-ism" – but a much more difficult fit for other teams.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2017/aug/14/premier-league-10-talking-points-from-the-opening-weekends-action|title=Premier League: 10 talking points from the opening weekend's action:Outstanding Vardy embodies Leicester-ism|work=Guardian newspapers|date=14 August 2017|accessdate=14 August 2017}} Shakespeare was sacked in October 2017 after four months officially in charge, with Leicester in 18th place in the table. {{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41656917|title=Craig Shakespeare: Leicester City sack manager four months after appointment|date=17 October 2017|accessdate=17 October 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}} [[Claude Puel]] was appointed as Leicester's new manager on 25 October 2017. By Christmas, Leicester were in 8th position in the Premier League and went on to finish one place lower in 9th at the end of the season. Despite rumors that Puel would leave, he remained at the club and from the first seven games in the [[2018–19 Premier League]] season, Puel's Leicester had accumulated 12 points, the same points tally after seven games as the [[2015–16 Premier League]] title winning campaign.https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/claude-puels-evolution-full-display-2059575 However, the team suffered a poor run of games which saw Leicester suffer 4 successive home defeats, and following a 4-1 home defeat to Crystal Palace, Puel was sacked on 24 February 2019 with the club in 12th place.https://www.lcfc.com/news/1062948/claude-puel-leaves-leicester-city/press-release Two days later on 26 February 2019, [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] manager [[Brendan Rodgers]], who nearly won the Premier League title with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], was appointed as his replacement. {{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47368712|title=Brendan Rodgers: Leicester City appoint former Celtic boss as manager|date=26 February 2019|accessdate=26 February 2019|publisher=BBC Sport}} ==== Helicopter crash ==== {{Main|2018 Leicester helicopter crash}} Club owner [[Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha]]'s helicopter crashed outside the King Power Stadium, shortly after taking off from the pitch on 27 October 2018, killing Srivaddhanaprabha and all four other people on board.{{cite news| title=Leicester City owner's helicopter crashes| url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leicestershire-46006470| newspaper=BBC News |date=27 October 2018}} {{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-leicestershire-46013381|title=Leicester City confirm chairman's death|date=2018-10-28|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-GB}} ==Colours, crest, nicknames and traditions== {{Football kit box | align =left | pattern_la = | pattern_b = _brightblueleftsash | pattern_ra = | pattern_sh = _brightblueline | leftarm = 000000 | body = 000000 | rightarm = 000000 | shorts = white | socks = 000000 | title = Leicester City's first home colours worn from 1884 to 1886. }} [[File:LCFC1948shirt.jpg|thumb|right|This shirt, worn in 1948, was the first to bear a club badge.]] The club's home colours of royal blue shirts, white shorts, and either white or royal blue socks have been used for the team's kits throughout most of its history.{{cite web|url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Leicester_City/Leicester_City.htm|title=Leicester City|publisher=Historical Football Kits|accessdate=17 September 2009}} The first sponsorship logo to appear on a Leicester shirt was that of [[Ind Coope]] in 1983. British snack food manufacturer [[Walkers Crisps]] held a long association with the club, sponsoring them from 1987 to 2001. [[File:LCFC 125 Years.png|thumb|right|Leicester City's badge for the [[2009–10 in English football|2009–10 season]] to commemorate 125 years as a football club.]] The club have three main nicknames – The Foxes, The Blues and City. "The Foxes" is the most common nickname for the club, whereas "The Blues" and "City" are more local terms, usually used by supporters. Other names include "The Filberts" and "The Fossils".{{Cite web | title = Where Did Leicester City Get Their Nickname From? | first = Sam | last = Fletcher | work = ThoughtCo. | date = 30 April 2017 | accessdate = 8 June 2018 | url = https://www.thoughtco.com/leicester-city-called-the-foxes-3896512}} An image of a [[fox]] was first incorporated into the club crest in 1948, as Leicestershire is known for foxes and fox hunting.{{cite web |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/180712-city-shirts-a-potted-history-248065.aspx |title=City Shirts – A Potted History | first=John | last=Hutchinson |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=18 July 2012|accessdate=31 October 2013}} This is the origin of the nickname "The Foxes". The club mascot is a character called "Filbert Fox". There are also secondary characters "Vickie Vixen" and "Cousin Dennis." Since 1992, the club's badge has featured a fox's head overlaid onto a Cinquefoil; the Cinquefoil is similar to the one used on the [[Leicester#Coat of arms|coat of arms of Leicester]]. Prior to 1992, the club's badge had a range of designs. In the [[2009–10 Leicester City F.C. season|2009–10 season]], the club's 125th anniversary year, the home kit featured no sponsor and a new central crest with "125 Years" written beneath it.{{Cite news|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-unveil-new-home-kit/story-12036491-detail/story.html|title=Leicester City unveil new home kit|date=25 April 2009|work=Leicester Mercury|accessdate=31 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150714213122/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-unveil-new-home-kit/story-12036491-detail/story.html|archivedate=14 July 2015}} In 1941, the club adopted the playing of the [[Post horn#The Post Horn Galop|Post Horn Galop]] prior to home matches.Official History DVD, 00:32:00 It was played over the PA system as the teams came out of the tunnel at all home games. The club since replaced it with a modern version, which is now played as teams emerge for the second half. For the first half, the post horn has been played live on pitch by Paul Hing since 2009.{{cite news |url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Rousing-tune-leads-way-City-victory/story-28948744-detail/story.html |title=Rousing tune leads way for City victory |newspaper=[[Leicester Mercury]] |date=18 March 2016 |accessdate=4 May 2016 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} "Foxes Never Quit" is the club's motto, which is placed above the tunnel entrance as the teams head out onto the pitch. On 8 July 2016, the club launched their new third away kit for the [[2016–17 Premier League]] season. It featured in their [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League]] campaign, and was also in use for Leicester's debut match in the competition. The design took inspiration from the 1983–84 kit, boasting a clean white design with thin blue pinstripes on the shirt and a textured form stripe design across both the shirt and shorts. ===Kit manufacturers and sponsors=== Since 2018, Leicester City's kit is manufactured by [[Adidas]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.footyheadlines.com/2018/05/no-more-puma-adidas-leicester-city-18-19-kit.html|title=No More Puma – Adidas Leicester City 18–19 Home Kit Revealed|work=Footy Headlines|date=1 June 2018|access-date=11 August 2018}} Previous manufacturers have included [[Bukta]] (1962–64, 1990–92), [[Admiral Sportswear|Admiral]] (1976–79, 1983–88), [[Umbro]] (1979–83), Scoreline (1988–90), Fox Leisure (1992–2000), [[Le Coq Sportif]] (2000–05), [[JJB Sports|JJB]] (2005–07), [[Jako]] (2007–09), [[Joma]] (2009–10), Burrda (2010–12),{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~2090129,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100715064409/http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10274~2090129%2C00.html |archivedate=15 July 2010 |title=Burrda Announced As Official Kit Supplier |publisher=LCFC.com |date=14 July 2010 |accessdate=31 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and [[Puma (brand)|Puma]] (2012–18).{{cite web |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/060713-lcfc-puma-unveil-1314-home-kit-898080.aspx |title=LCFC & PUMA Unveil 13/14 Home Kit|publisher=LCFC.com |date=6 July 2013|accessdate=31 October 2013}} The main shirt sponsor is [[King Power]], a company also owned by the club's owners. The first sponsorship logo to appear on a Leicester shirt was that of [[Ind Coope]] in 1983. British snack food manufacturer [[Walkers Crisps]] held a long association with the club, sponsoring them from 1987 to 2001. Other sponsors have included [[Star Brewery|John Bull]] (1986–87), [[LG Corporation|LG]] (2001–03), [[Alliance & Leicester]] (2003–07), [[Topps Tiles]] (2007–09), [[Jessops]] (2009–10), and Loros (2009–10). [[Siam Commercial Bank]] became their first sleeve sponsor. The deal was valid for the [[2017–18 Leicester City F.C. season|2017–18 season]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.lcfc.com/news/438270/siam-commercial-bank-to-be-leicester-city-sleeve-sponsor/press-release|title=Siam Commercial Bank To Be Leicester City Sleeve Sponsor|date=15 July 2017|publisher=Leicester City F.C.|access-date=1 June 2018}} For the [[2018–19 Leicester City F.C. season|2018–19 season]], the sleeve sponsor is [[Sabeco Brewery|Bia Saigon]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.lcfc.com/news/792418/leicester-city-and-thaibev-agree-multiyear-global-partnership/press-release|title=Leicester City And ThaiBev Agree Multi-Year Global Partnership|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en}} ==Stadium== {{See also|King Power Stadium|Filbert Street}} In their early years, Leicester played at numerous grounds, but have only played at two since they joined the [[Football League]]. When first starting out they played on a field by the Fosse Road,{{Cite book|last=Inglis |first=Simon |title=The Football Grounds of Great Britain (2nd ed.) |publisher=Collins Willow |location=London |year=1987 |isbn = 0-00-218249-1|page=136}} hence the original name Leicester Fosse. They moved from there to [[Victoria Park, Leicester|Victoria Park]], and subsequently to Belgrave Road. Upon turning professional the club moved to Mill Lane. After eviction from Mill Lane the club played at the County Cricket ground while seeking a new ground. The club secured the use of an area of ground by [[Filbert Street]], and moved there in 1891. [[File:Double Decker Stand at Filbert Street.jpg|thumb|left|The "Double Decker" Stand at [[Filbert Street]]]] Some improvements by noted football architect [[Archibald Leitch]] occurred in the Edwardian era, and in 1927 a new two tier stand was built, named the Double Decker, a name it would keep till the ground's closure in 2002. The ground wasn't developed any further, apart from compulsory seating being added, till 1993 when work began on the new Carling Stand. The stand was impressive while the rest of the ground was untouched since at least the 1920s; this led manager [[Martin O'Neill]] to say he used to "lead new signings out backwards" so they only saw the Carling Stand.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/095235361X |title=Author notes on ''Farewell to Filbert Street'' |publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=3 September 2011}} The club moved away from Filbert Street in 2002 to a new 32,500 all-seater stadium.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/2146706.stm|title=Lineker unveils new Foxes home|date=23 July 2002|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=31 October 2013}} The stadium was originally named The [[Walkers Stadium]] in a deal with food manufacturers [[Walkers (snack foods)|Walkers]], whose brand logo can still be found in some areas around the outside of the stadium.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2002/apr/10/newsstory.sport1|title=Fans force Foxes stadium change|date=10 April 2002|work=The Guardian|accessdate=31 October 2013 | location=London}} The first match hosted at Walkers was a 1–1 friendly draw against [[Athletic Bilbao]], with Bilbao's [[Tiko (footballer)|Tiko]] being the first scorer at the stadium and [[Jordan Stewart (footballer, born 1982)|Jordan Stewart]] being the first Leicester player to score.{{Cite news|url=http://www.eldia.es/2002-08-05/jornada/jornada15.htm|title=Empate del Athletic Bilbao|date=5 August 2002|work=El Dia|language=Spanish|accessdate=19 September 2009}} The first competitive match was a 2–0 victory against Watford.{{Cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1708638.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131108172404/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1708638.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=8 November 2013|title=Leicester make a tidy profit from Deane double|last=Leach|first=Conrad|date=11 August 2002|work=The Independent |accessdate=31 October 2013 | location=London}} The stadium has since hosted an [[England national football team|England]] international against [[Serbia and Montenegro national football team|Serbia and Montenegro]], which finished 2–1 to England, as well as internationals between [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] and [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]], and Jamaica and [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]]. The stadium has been used to host the [[Heineken Cup]] European Rugby semi-finals for the [[Leicester Tigers]] rugby club, itself based within a mile of the King Power Stadium. [[File:King Power Stadium.JPG|thumbnail|right|The King Power Stadium, formerly known as the Walker's Stadium, has been Leicester's home ground since 2002]] On 19 August 2010, it emerged that the new owners [[King Power]] wanted to rename the stadium The [[King Power Stadium]], and had plans to increase the capacity to 42,000 should Leicester secure promotion.{{cite news|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/CHANGE-WALKERS-STADIUM/story-12075059-detail/story.html|title=Leicester City's Walkers Stadium could be renamed and increased in size|work=Leicester Mercury|accessdate=31 October 2013|date=19 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151002171927/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/CHANGE-WALKERS-STADIUM/story-12075059-detail/story.html|archivedate=2 October 2015}} On 7 July 2011, Leicester City confirmed the Walkers Stadium would now be known as the King Power Stadium. In 2015, vice-chairman [[Aiyawatt Srivaddhanaprabha]] stated plans were in place to increase the capacity of the stadium to around 42,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-increase-capacity-King-Power/story-26656839-detail/story.html|title=Leicester City could increase capacity at the King Power Stadium to 42,000|work=Leicester Mercury|date=8 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160102235844/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-increase-capacity-King-Power/story-26656839-detail/story.html|archivedate=2 January 2016}} Relocation to a bigger stadium has also been considered.{{cite web|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/leicester-city-look-ground-expansion-build-new/story-29238169-detail/story.html|title=Leicester City look at King Power stadium expansion – or may even build new ground|work=Leicester Mercury|date=6 May 2016}} In April 2018, it was announced that initial planning for the expansion and development of the King Power Stadium is underway.{{cite press release| url=https://www.lcfc.com/news/657242/vice-chairman-confirms-king-power-stadium-expansion-ambitions/press-release| title=Vice Chairman Confirms King Power Stadium Expansion Ambitions| date=10 April 2018| publisher=Leicester City F.C.|accessdate=8 June 2018}} The King Power Stadium has also honoured past greats of the club, by naming suites and lounges inside the stadium after the club's former players [[Gordon Banks]], [[Adam Black (footballer, born 1898)|Adam Black]], [[Arthur Chandler (footballer)|Arthur Chandler]], [[Gary Lineker]], [[Arthur Rowley]], [[Sep Smith]], [[Keith Weller]] and former manager [[Jimmy Bloomfield]].{{cite web|title=King Power Stadium – Function Suites|url=http://www.lcfcevents.co.uk/downloads/LCFC%20CE%20Insert%20-%20Room%20Plans.pdf#page=2|publisher=Leicester City Football Club Conference & Events – Room Plans|accessdate=31 October 2013}} ==Financial Fair Play Rules Breach== Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha invested more than £140m over 14/15 to 16/17, including more than £40 million in the clubs's Premiership winning season.{{cite web|title=Ranking the Premier League clubs' spending |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/04/25/ranking-premier-league-clubs-spending-past-three-seasons/leicester/|publisher=Daily Telegraph Newspaper}} In 2018 the club paid £3.1m to settle the English Football League’s claim that the club breached financial fair play rules when they made a £21m loss (£12m over the guidelines) in their Championship winning 2013-14 season. {{cite web|title=Leicester make £3.1m settlement |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/21/leicester-settlement-football-league-ffp|publisher=Guardian Newspaper}} ==Rival clubs== {{main|Leicester City F.C. and Nottingham Forest F.C. rivalry|Derby County F.C. and Leicester City F.C. rivalry|M69 derby}} Some Leicester fans consider [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] to be their main rivals. The club's other rivals are [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]]. An East Midlands Derby is any match involving two of these three clubs.{{cite web |url=http://www.footballfanscensus.com/issueresults/Club_Rivalries_Uncovered_Results.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020074918/http://www.footballfanscensus.com/issueresults/Club_Rivalries_Uncovered_Results.pdf |archivedate=20 October 2013 |title=Club Rivalries Uncovered |publisher= Football Fans Census|date=December 2003 |accessdate=31 October 2013}} Leicester also have a rivalry with [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]], 24 miles away. The game between the two clubs has become known as the [[M69 derby]], named after the [[M69 motorway]] which connects the two cities together.{{Cite news|author=Sinclair, John | title=Leicester v Coventry | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/leicester/content/articles/2007/02/16/lcfc_coventry_home_17feb2007_event_feature.shtml|publisher=BBC Sport| date=17 February 2007| accessdate=17 June 2009}} League War Cup]]''' ** '''Winners (1):''' 1941 ==Managerial history== {{Main|List of Leicester City F.C. managers}} Up until [[Peter Hodge]] was hired after World War I, the club had no official manager. A nominal role of secretary/manager was employed, though the board and the selection committee took control of most team affairs. It was Hodge who instated a system at the club for the manager having complete control over player and staff recruitment, team selection and tactics. Though Hodge was originally also titled "secretary/manager" he has retrospectively been named as the club's first official "manager".{{Cite book|author=Dave Smith & Paul Taylor|title=Of Fossils and Foxes|year=2010|isbn=1-905411-94-4}} Leicester have had a total of nine permanent secretary/managers and 36 permanent managers (not including caretakers). [[Nigel Pearson]] and Peter Hodge have both had two separate spells in charge of the club. [[Dave Bassett]] also had a second spell as caretaker manager after his spell as permanent manager.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/Records/0,,10274~1035220,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120218091401/http://www.lcfc.com/page/Records/0%2C%2C10274~1035220%2C00.html |archivedate=18 February 2012 |title=Past Managers |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=20 June 2008 |accessdate=31 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Records and statistics== {{Main|List of Leicester City F.C. records and statistics}} [[Graham Cross]] holds the record for the most Leicester appearances, with the defender playing 599 games between 1960–1976, although [[Adam Black (footballer, born 1898)|Adam Black]] holds the record for the most appearances in the league with 528 between 1920–1935.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/Records/0,,10274~1028896,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120722013638/http://www.lcfc.com/page/Records/0%2C%2C10274~1028896%2C00.html |archivedate=22 July 2012 |title=Most Appearances |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=23 September 2009 |accessdate=31 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Striker [[Arthur Chandler (footballer)|Arthur Chandler]] is currently the club's all-time record goal scorer, netting 273 in his 12 years at the club; he also found the net in 8 consecutive matches in the 1924–25 season. The most goals managed in a single season for the club is 44 by [[Arthur Rowley]], in the 1956–57 season. The fastest goal in the club's history was scored by [[Matty Fryatt]], when he netted after just nine seconds against [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] in April 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/Records/0,,10274~1028984,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090330135817/http://www.lcfc.com/page/Records/0%2C%2C10274~1028984%2C00.html |archivedate=30 March 2009 |title=Miscellaneous Records |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=30 May 2008 |accessdate=31 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[Jamie Vardy]] broke the Premier League record for scoring 13 goals in 11 consecutive league games, in the 2015–16 Premier League season. Vardy is also the ninth player to score 20 top-flight goals in a season, following Arthur Chandler, Ernie Hine, Arthur Rowley, Jimmy Walsh, Ken Keyworth, Jackie Sinclair, Frank Worthington and Gary Lineker. Vardy's goal at Sunderland on 10 April 2016 saw him become the first player since Gary Lineker in 1984–85 to score 20 top flight goals for the club, having already become Leicester's highest Premier League scorer in a single season.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/champions-citys-record-breaking-season-3093033.aspx|title=CHAMPIONS: City's Record-Breaking Season|date=4 May 2016 |publisher=Leicester City F.C.}} The record transfer fee paid by Leicester for a player was around £29 million for [[Sporting CP]] striker [[Islam Slimani]]. The highest transfer fee received for a Leicester player was approximately £60 million from Manchester City for midfielder [[Riyad Mahrez]]. The club's record attendance is 47,298 against Tottenham Hotspur at [[Filbert Street]], in a fifth round [[FA Cup]] clash in 1928. The highest league record at their current home, the [[King Power Stadium]], was 32,242 for a competitive match against Sunderland on 8 August 2015. The highest ever attendance for a non-competitive football match of 32,188, was seen at a pre-season friendly against Spanish giants [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] on 30 July 2011.{{cite news | title = Record crowd watch Leicester City play Real Madrid | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14363378 | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 1 August 2011 | accessdate = 31 October 2013 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20121105144938/http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14363378 | archive-date = 5 November 2012 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} Leicester's highest ever league finish is first in the Premier League in [[2015–16 Premier League|2015–16]]. Their lowest ever league finish was first in League One in [[2008–09 in English football|2008–09]]. Leicester are joint equal with [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] for having won the most [[List of winners of English Football League Championship and predecessors|English second tier]] titles (7). The club has reached four [[FA Cup]] finals, yet lost them all. This is the record for the most [[FA Cup]] final appearances without winning the trophy. Leicester's longest ever unbeaten run in the league was between 1 November 2008 and 7 March 2009, to which they remained unbeaten for 23 games on their way to the [[Football League One|League One]] title.{{Cite news|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/escape-act-time-City/story-12077324-detail/story.html|title=No escape act this time, City!|date=12 March 2009|work=Leicester Mercury|accessdate=31 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151002163403/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/escape-act-time-City/story-12077324-detail/story.html|archivedate=2 October 2015}} (This was their only ever season in the third tier of English football). Their longest run of consecutive victories in the league is nine, which they achieved between 21 December 2013 and 1 February 2014 (in the Championship). In the 2015–16 season, Leicester won what ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' described as "one of the most astonishing league titles of all-time"{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/12/10/leicester-city-vs-man-city-premier-league-live/|title=Leicester City 4 Man City 2: Foxes find their ferocious side as Jamie Vardy hat-trick ends 16 match goal drought|author=Sam Wallace|date=10 December 2016|accessdate=11 December 2016}} and achieved many new historical, club records. They had the fewest away defeats in any top flight season, as they were defeated only twice on their travels. They also recorded the fewest losses in any of the club's Premier League seasons, losing just three matches throughout their entire campaign. The club produced another record for the most consecutive wins in the top flight, each coming against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and Sunderland. Coincidentally, they kept a record of five-straight clean sheets all set against each of the same five opponents. The King Power Stadium home crowd in 2015–16 saw City beaten just once in the Premier League all season. Leicester made their [[UEFA Champions League]] debut in the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|2016–17 season]], their fourth appearance in European football. The club became the third English team to win on their Champions League debut, after Manchester United in 1994 and Newcastle United in 1997. They are also the first English team to win away on their Champions League debut, and win all three of their opening games in the competition.{{cite tweet |user=TheOddsBible |number=788483770680745984 |date=18 October 2016 |title=Leicester are the first English side ever to win their first three Champions League games}}{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2016/09/27/leicester-city-become-first-english-team-to-win-their-first-two-champions-league-games-6156977/|title=Leicester City make BEST EVER start to Champions League life by English club|first=Max |last=Miller |work=Metro.co.uk|date=27 September 2016}} They are the first team in Champions League history to keep clean sheets in each of their opening four games in the competition.{{cite tweet |user=SkySportsStatto |number=793930648390078464 |date=2 November 2016 |title=@LCFC are the 1st team in Champions League history to keep clean sheets in their opening 4 games in the competition }} In the club's [[2015–16 Premier League]] title winning season, between September 2015 and November 2016 the team went 20 league games unbeaten at home. The stint was ended by [[West Bromwich Albion]] on 6 November 2016 in a 1–2 defeat.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/06/leicester-city-west-bromwich-albion-premier-league-match-report|title=West Bromwich's Matt Phillips pounces to end Leicester's unbeaten home run|first=Paul| last=Doyle|date=6 November 2016|work=The Guardian}}{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/transfer/news/11096/10641971/leicester8217s-unbeaten-premier-league-home-record-is-among-the-best-in-europe|title=Leicester's unbeaten Premier League home record is among the best in Europe|work=[[Sky Sports]]|date=3 November 2016|accessdate=3 December 2016}} In March 2017, the club became the 50th team to reach the Champions League quarter-finals. ==League history== {{See also|List of Leicester City F.C. seasons}} Since their election to the [[Football League]] in 1894, Leicester have spent much of their history within the top two tiers of English football. Leicester have played outside the top two tiers only once in their history to date; during the [[2008–09 in English football|2008–09]] season they played in [[Football League One|League One]], the third tier of English football, after relegation from [[Football League Championship|the Championship]] the season prior. However, they made a swift return to the second tier, as they were promoted as champions in the [[2008–09 in English football|2008–09 season]].
