==Owners== {{Updated|20 April 2018}}
Chairman Mike Garlick holds 49.24% of outstanding shares of Burnley F.C. and Member of the [[Board of Directors]] John Banaszkiewicz another 28.2%. The other five Members of the Board hold, between them, a total of 16.36%. The total holding of shares by all Board members amounts to 93.8%.<ref>[https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/club/contact/ Board of Directors], Burnley FC</ref>
Burnley is one of the few clubs in the top two tiers who are British-owned. Every director at the club is locally born, a ''Claret'' supporter and none of them are getting paid. As of 2018–19, the club is debt-free.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-4975022/Brendan-Flood-reveals-secrets-Burnley-s-success.html|title=Burnley's secret and a choppy helicopter ride with Neville and Giggs|last=|first=|date=|work=Mail Online|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref>
== Kits, colours and crest ==
=== Kits and colours === In the early years, various designs and colours were used by Burnley. Throughout their first eight years these were various permutations of blue and white. After three years of claret and amber stripes with black shorts, for much of the 1890s a combination of black with amber stripes was used, although the club wore a shirt with pink and white stripes during the [[1894–95 Football League|1894–95]] season. Between 1897 and 1900 the club used a plain red shirt and from 1900 until 1910 the club changed to an all green shirt with white shorts. In 1910 the club changed their colours to claret and sky blue, the colours that they have now had for the majority of their history, save for a spell in white shirts and black shorts during the 1930s.<ref name="historicalkits" /> The adoption of the claret and sky blue colour combination were a homage to league champions [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], who wore those colours. The Burnley committee and manager [[John Haworth]] believed it might bring a change of fortune.<ref name=":0" />
Burnley's away kit for the [[2006–07 Burnley F.C. season|2006–07]] season, a yellow shirt with claret bar, yellow shorts and yellow socks, won the ''Best Kit Design'' award at the [[EFL Awards|Football League Awards]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/1238010.Clarets_win_kit_award/|title=Clarets win kit award|website=Lancashire Telegraph|language=en|access-date=26 January 2018}}</ref> The [[2007–08 Burnley F.C. season|following season]], a new home kit was released, echoing the 1950s shirt; all claret with a blue v-neck and rims on the end of the arms which sport the word '''Burnley''<nowiki/>'. It featured gold trim and a new gold logo for the club's 125th anniversary. For the Championship match against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on 24 November 2007, Burnley wore a commemorative 125th anniversary shirt based on their first kit; blue and white stripes with black trim/shorts and white socks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/English_Football_League/season/2007-2008/championship.html|title=The Championship 2007–2008 – Historical Football Kits|website=www.historicalkits.co.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=26 January 2018}}</ref> For the [[2009–10 Burnley F.C. season|2009–10]] season, the club wore a kit similar to the kit worn when Burnley won the old First Division title (i.e. what is now the Premier League title) in [[1959–60 Burnley F.C. season|1959–60]], to commemorate the 50th anniversary of that achievement.
Since 2010, Burnley's kits have been manufactured by [[Puma (brand)|Puma]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/business/4864368.Burnley_sign_new_Puma_kit_deal/|title=Burnley sign new Puma kit deal|last=|first=|date=21 January 2010|website=Lancashire Telegraph|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=8 August 2018}}</ref> Previous manufacturers include [[Umbro]] (1975–81), Spall (1981–87, 1988–89), En-s (1987–88), Ellgren (1989–91), Ribero (1991–93), [[Mitre Sports International|Mitre]] (1993–96), [[Adidas]] (1996–99), Super League (1999–2002), TFG Sports (2002–05), and [[Erreà]] (2005–10).<ref name="historicalkits" /> The clubs shirts are currently sponsored by LaBa360.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.soccerex.com/insight/articles/2018/burnley-announce-record-breaking-shirt-sponsor-deal|title=Burnley announce ‘record-breaking’ shirt sponsor deal|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=24 July 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Previous shirt sponsors include POCO (1982–83), [[TSB Bank (United Kingdom)|TSB]] (1983–84), [[Multipart Solutions|Multipart]] (1984–88), [[Endsleigh Insurance|Endsleigh]] (1988–98), P3 Computers (1998–2000), Lanway (2001–04), Hunters (2004–07), [[Holland's Pies|Holland's]] (2007–09), Cooke (2009–10), Fun88 (2010–12, 2014–15), Premier Range (2012–14), [[Oak Furniture Land]] (2015–16), and [[Dafabet]] (2016–18).<ref name="historicalkits" />
=== Crest === [[File:Royal Coat of Arms of the United Kingdom.svg|thumb|The Royal Arms]] ''The Clarets''' first recorded usage of a crest was on 17 December 1887, when they wore the [[Prince of Wales|Prince of Wales' coat of arms]] on their shirt.<ref name="historicalkits" /> The Prince of Wales visited Turf Moor a year before when Burnley was playing Bolton Wanderers, which was the first ever visit by a member of the [[British royal family|Royal Family]].<ref name=":16">Fiszman, Marc; Peters, Mark (2005). Kick Off Championship 2005–06. Sidan Press. p. 15.</ref> Afterwards, Burnley were presented a set of white jerseys featuring a blue sash and embellished with the Prince of Wales' coat of arms to commemorate the visit, making ''the Clarets'' the first ever club to have the right to wear it on their shirts.<ref name=claretsmad.co.uk>{{Cite web|url=http://www.clarets-mad.co.uk/feat/ed93/ask_clarets_mad_answers_7_108144/index.shtml|title=Ask Clarets Mad Answers 7 – Clarets Mad|last=LTD|first=Digital Sports Group|website=www.clarets-mad.co.uk|language=en|access-date=19 June 2018}}</ref> The club would regularly wear the royal crest until the [[1894–95 Football League|1894–95]] season. Twenty years later, when Burnley played the [[1914 FA Cup Final]] and [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]] was in attendance, the Royal Arms featured once again on the ''claret and blue'' shirts.<ref name="historicalkits" />
A forerunner of the club's current badge was first recorded in 1935. 25 years later, when Burnley won the league title for a second time, they were allowed to wear the town's crest of the period on their shirts.<ref name=":17">{{Cite web|url=http://www.clarets-mad.co.uk/feat/ed93/ask_clarets_mad_answers_7_108144/index.shtml|title=Ask Clarets Mad Answers 7 – Clarets Mad|last=LTD|first=Digital Sports Group|website=www.clarets-mad.co.uk|language=en|access-date=19 June 2018}}</ref> The town's crest was worn until the [[1969–70 Football League|1969–70]] season, when it was replaced with a simple "''BFC''". Six years later, the initials were lettered with gold. Four seasons after that, the club used a new designed badge based on the town's crest, before returning to a horizontal version of the "''BFC''" initials in 1983, which were lettered in white this time.<ref name="historicalkits" /> In the [[1987–88 Burnley F.C. season|1987–88]] season they returned to their former, new designed crest.
The latest major change to the club crest came in the [[2009–10 Burnley F.C. season|2009–10]] season. To mark Burnley's first ever season in the [[Premier League]], since the rebranding of the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] in 1992, and to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the club's 1959–60 First Division league title win, Burnley decided to return to the crest used in that title winning season.<ref name="historicalkits" /> [[2010–11 Burnley F.C. season|The following season]], the town's Latin motto "''Pretiumque Et Causa Laboris''" (English translation: "''The prize and the cause of our labour''") was replaced with the inscription "''Burnley Football Club''".<ref name=sbnation>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2015/1/16/7557207/burnley-badge-premier-league|title=Burnley's badge is the best in the Premier League|work=SBNation.com|access-date=19 June 2018}}</ref>
Burnley's current badge is based on the town's crest and many components of the badge — depicting cotton, history, industry, royalty — have their origins in the history of the club, the town [[Burnley]] and surrounding areas and the components thus refer to them.<ref name=sbnation />
==Club mascot== The club's mascot is Dyche the Dick Dressed in a bee suit, he wears the Burnley home kit with shirt number 1882 and is popular with the Burnley fans.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/10209230.Video__Film_shows_day_in_the_life_of_Clarets_mascot_Bertie_Bee/|title=Video: Film shows day in the life of Clarets mascot Bertie Bee|last=|first=|date=|website=Lancashire Telegraph|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 August 2018}}</ref> He became known nationwide for rugby tackling a streaker on the pitch at Turf Moor who had evaded the stewards during a match against local rivals Preston in 2002, and appeared on the BBC Television sporting panel show [[They Think It's All Over (TV series)|''They Think It's All Over'']] after the event.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.burnleyexpress.net/news/offbeat/video-bertie-bee-how-rugby-tackling-a-streaker-changed-my-career-1-3180956|title=VIDEO: Bertie Bee – how rugby tackling a streaker changed my career|website=www.burnleyexpress.net|language=en|access-date=26 January 2018}}</ref>
During the 2006–07 season, he was joined by [[Holland's Pies]] mascot ''Stan the Pie Man'', due to a sponsorship deal.<ref name=BurnleyFCMiscellany2014>{{Cite book|title=Burnley FC Miscellany: Everything you ever needed to know about The Clarets|last=Clayton|first=David|publisher=|year=2014|isbn=9781445642239|location=|pages=}}</ref> In October 2013, he again hit the headlines, this time after a top of the table clash against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|QPR]], when he was sent off and 'jailed' after he jokingly offered the assistant referee a pair of glasses.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/burnley-mascot-sent-jailed-after-2644050|title=Burnley mascot sent off and 'jailed' after offering official his glasses|last=Richards|first=Alex|date=26 October 2013|work=mirror|access-date=26 January 2018}}</ref>
==Stadium== {{Main|Turf Moor}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Turf Moor | nickname = ''"The Turf"'' | image = James Hargreaves Stand Burnley.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = The James Hargreaves Stand | image_alt = A two-tiered cantilever football stand. The lower tier has light blue seats with some claret seats which spell the word "Clarets". The upper has all claret seating. Some floodlights are attached to the roof of the stand. A scattering of spectators can be seen in the seats. | location = [[Burnley]], [[Lancashire]] | broke_ground = 1833 (as a cricket ground)<ref name=BookBaby18>{{cite book |last1=Burden |first1=Brian |last2=Morse |first2=Blair |title=The Sports Tourists' Guide to the English Premier League |publisher=BookBaby |year=2018 |isbn=978-1543919554}}</ref> | tenants = [[Burnley Cricket Club]] {on larger site} (1833–1883)<br />'''Burnley Football Club''' {current site} (1883–present) | seating_capacity = 21,944 ''(all-seated)''<ref name="PL">{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/clubs/43/Burnley/stadium |title=Turf Moor |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=16 June 2018 }}</ref> | coordinates = {{coord|53|47|21|N|2|13|49|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = United Kingdom Burnley | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Burnley }} Burnley have played their home games at Turf Moor since 1883, after playing at its original ground at ''Calder Vale'' for less than a year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.11v11.com/teams/burnley/|title=Burnley football club overview|last=|first=|date=|website=www.11v11.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.footballhistory.org/club/burnley.html|title=Burnley FC|last=|first=|date=|website=www.footballhistory.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 June 2018}}</ref> Turf Moor is the longest continuously used ground of any of the 49 teams which have played in the Premier League and the second oldest continually used site for professional league football in the world, behind [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston]]'s [[Deepdale]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/4763572.Burnley_chairman__I_d_love_to_buy_back_the_Turf_Moor/|title=Burnley chairman: I'd love to buy back the Turf Moor|last=|first=|date=27 November 2009|website=Lancashire Telegraph|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The stadium is located on [[Harry Potts]] Way, named in honour of the club's longest serving manager.
In October 1886, Turf Moor welcomed the first-ever visit by a member of the [[Royal family|Royal Family]] to a first-class association football match at a senior ground, when [[Queen Victoria]]'s grandson, [[Prince Albert Victor, Duke of Clarence and Avondale|Prince Albert Victor]], was in attendance for a match between Burnley and [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/2017/december/the-story-of-the-dr-dean-trophy/|title=The Story Of The Dr Dean Trophy|last=Simpson|first=Ray|date=5 December 2017|work=Burnley Football Club|language=en-gb}}</ref> In 1888, the first Football League match at Turf Moor was an encounter against the same opposition, Bolton, with Burnley emerging as 4–1 winners, [[Fred Poland]] scoring the first competitive league goal at the stadium.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Origins of the Football League: The First Season 1888/89|last=Metcalf|first=Mark|publisher=Amberley Publishing|year=2013|isbn=978-1445618814|location=|pages=}}</ref> In [[1921–22 FA Cup|1922]], the ground hosted its only [[FA Cup semi-finals|FA Cup semi-final]] to date, between [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] and [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]], and five years later it hosted its only senior international match, between [[England national football team|England]] and [[Wales national football team|Wales]] for the [[British Home Championship]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://englandstats.com/matches.php?mid=158|title=England 1–2 Wales, British Home Championship|last=|first=|date=|website=englandstats.com|language=en-UK|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 June 2018}}</ref>
The Turf Moor site was first used for sport in 1833, when [[Burnley Cricket Club]] was established. Fifty years later, they invited Burnley Football Club to move from their original premises at ''Calder Vale'' to a pitch adjacent to the cricket field.<ref name=":14">{{cite book |last1=Burden |first1=Brian |last2=Morse |first2=Blair |title=The Sports Tourists' Guide to the English Premier League |publisher=BookBaby |year=2018 |isbn=978-1543919554}}</ref> The ground originally consisted of just a pitch and the first grandstand was not built until 1885.<ref name=footballstadiumsweb>{{Cite news|url=http://www.football-stadiums.co.uk/grounds/england/turf-moor/|title=Turf Moor|date=|work=Football Stadiums|access-date=16 June 2018|language=en-gb}}</ref> It now consists of 4 stands, the James Hargreaves Stand (''The Longside''), the [[Jimmy McIlroy]] Stand (''Bee Hole End''), the Bob Lord Stand and the Ladbrokes Stand (''The Cricket Field Stand'') for home and away fans. The current capacity is 21,944 all-seated.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/clubs/43/Burnley/stadium|title=Turf Moor Burnley FC, Info & Map {{!}} Premier League|website=www.premierleague.com|language=en|access-date=25 January 2018}}</ref> Post-World War I crowds in the stadium averaged in the 30,000–40,000 range with the record attendance set in 1924 against Huddersfield Town in a FA Cup match when 54,755 attended the match.<ref name=BurnleypremiumTV>{{Cite web|url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/History/0,,10413~1031447,00.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080309101845/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/History/0,,10413~1031447,00.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=9 March 2008|title=The Turf Moor Story {{!}} Burnley {{!}} Club {{!}} History {{!}} History|date=9 March 2008|access-date=25 January 2018}}</ref> On 23 February 1960, in a fifth round FA Cup replay against [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]], there was an official reported attendance of 52,850 at the Turf. Some of the gates were, however, broken down and many uncounted fans poured into the ground. Many supporters were also locked out, and the road from Bradford over the Moss at [[Colne]] had to be closed to traffic.<ref> http://www.thefootballnetwork.net/main/s37/st112457.htm </ref> Until 1974, ''The Turf'' had a slight slope in the field, when chairman Bob Lord made a resolution to relay the pitch and to remove the slope.<ref name=":14" /> During the 1990s, the ground underwent further refurbishment when ''The Longside'' and ''Bee Hole End'' terraces were replaced by all-seater stands as a result of the [[Taylor Report]], reducing the capacity in the process.<ref name=footballstadiumsweb />
In 2008, plans were made to extend the stadium to a capacity of around 28,000.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/burnley/5386898/10-things-you-probably-didnt-know-about-Burnley.html|title=10 things you probably didn't know about Burnley|last=Smith|first=Rory|date=26 May 2009|access-date=25 January 2018|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> This capacity increase would include a second tier attached to the Bob Lord stand, along with a complete re-development of the stand. In addition, a new stand was planned to replace the Cricket Field Stand, which would also hold a cricket pavilion and hotel. In late 2008, these plans were put on hold as general economic conditions worsened in the UK.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pitchcare.com/news-media/a-drop-of-claret.html|title=A Drop of Claret {{!}} Pitchcare|website=www.pitchcare.com|access-date=25 January 2018}}</ref>
At the end of 2017, Burnley finalised plans to develop two corners of the stadium (between the Jimmy McIlroy stand and both the James Hargreaves and Bob Lord stands) to provide better facilities for disabled supporters to meet the ''Accessible Stadium Guide'' (ASG) regulations.<ref name=December2017>{{Cite news|url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/2017/december/disabled-to-get-new-facilities-in-turf-moor-facelift/|title=Burnley Football Club Disabled Fans To Get New Facilities In Turf Moor Facelift|access-date=25 January 2018|language=en-gb}}</ref> The plans took the spending on infrastructure at the club to around £20m in two years, including a bigger club shop and ticket office at the stadium, and a major uplift to their training centre.
At the same time, however, the club concluded that "there will be no other ground developments to increase the overall capacity of Turf Moor in the short-term, unless an increase in demand for seats forces a re-think."<ref name=December2017 />
==Supporters and rivalries==
=== Supporters === Burnley is one of the best supported clubs in English football per head of population, with average attendances of 20,000 in the Premier League in a town with approximately [[Burnley|73,000]] inhabitants.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/2843529/burnley-chief-mike-garlick-has-acquired-a-taste-for-keeping-the-prem-league-battlers-in-rude-health/|title=Burnley chief Mike Garlick has acquired a taste for keeping the Prem League battlers in rude health|date=12 February 2017|work=The Sun|access-date=25 December 2017|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref name="eurostats">{{Cite web|url=http://www.european-football-statistics.co.uk/england.htm|title=EFS English Clubs|website=www.european-football-statistics.co.uk|access-date=29 January 2018}}</ref> In the championship winning year of [[1959–60 Burnley F.C. season|1959–60]], the fan-ratio of Burnley was twice the top flight average.<ref name="Never Had it So Good" /> Although as well as having a loyal, local fan base, ''the Clarets'' also have numerous [[Supporters' groups|supporters' clubs]] across the United Kingdom<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/fans/supporters-clubs/|title=Burnley Football Club – Supporters Clubs|last=|first=|date=|website=www.burnleyfootballclub.com|language=en-gb|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref> and overseas, with supporters' clubs in Australia, Canada, Finland, Nigeria, Poland, Republic of Ireland, Spain, Thailand, and United States amongst others.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.myburnleyfc.com/find-a-club/#!directory/map|title=Club Finder|last=|first=|date=|website=www.myburnleyfc.com|language=en-GB|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref>
When falling down to the lower leagues and the simultaneously growing presence of [[Football hooliganism in the United Kingdom|hooliganism in English football]] in the 1980s, a [[List of hooligan firms|hooligan firm]] linked to Burnley was established, called the "''[[Suicide Squad (hooligan firm)|Suicide Squad]]"'', which became infamous for violently clashing with many other firms and fans in the country.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Suicide Squad: The Inside Story of a Football Firm|last=Porter|first=Andrew|publisher=Milo Books|year=2005|isbn=9781903854464|location=|pages=}}</ref> They also featured in the television documentary series ''[[The Real Football Factories]]'' presented by [[Danny Dyer]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/archives/news/318191/thugs-jailed-over-football-gang-fight/|title=Thugs jailed over football gang fight|date=19 January 2011|work=The Sun|access-date=4 February 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref> The squad officially disbanded in 2009 after a high-profile incident with supporters of [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], in which afterwards twelve members of the ''Suicide Squad'' were sentenced to jail for a total of 32 years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/8797259.Burnley__Suicide_Squad__hooligans_jailed_for_32_years/|title=Burnley 'Suicide Squad' hooligans jailed for 32 years|website=Lancashire Telegraph|language=en|access-date=4 February 2018}}</ref>
Notable fans over the years have included football coach [[Jimmy Hogan]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thejimmyhoganstory.wordpress.com/|title=The Jimmy Hogan Story|last=|first=|date=|website=|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref> Prime Minister [[Edward Heath]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2101443/Prince-Charles-admits-Burnley-FC-Fan.html|title='Closet Claret': Prince Charles admits to being a Burnley FC Fan|last=|first=|date=|work=Mail Online|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref> [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], journalist [[Alastair Campbell]], [[2003 Superbike World Championship|Superbike]] world champion [[Neil Hodgson]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.neilhodgson100.com/profile.html|title=Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=www.neilhodgson100.com|language=en-gb|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref> [[BBC Radio 1]] DJ [[Jordan North]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.burnleyexpress.net/news/radio-1-slot-for-talented-burnley-dj-1-8996928|title=Radio 1 slot for talented Burnley DJ|last=|first=|date=|website=www.burnleyexpress.net|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 February 2019}}</ref> and cricketer [[James Anderson (cricketer)|James Anderson]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.clitheroeadvertiser.co.uk/news/offbeat/who-is-burnley-fc-s-biggest-fan-1-4294192|title=Who is Burnley FC’s biggest fan?|last=|first=|date=|work=Clitheroe Advertiser and Times|access-date=16 August 2018|language=en}}</ref>
=== Rivalries === {{Main|East Lancashire derby}} In an unofficial ''Football Rivalry Survey'' from 2012–13, Burnley were listed 7th out of a list of 92 respective Football League clubs with the most rivals, with [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] considering Burnley to be their main rival and [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]], [[Morecambe F.C.|Morecambe]] and [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] considering them their second main rival.<ref name="wordpress.com">{{Cite news|url=https://thechriswhitingshow.wordpress.com/2012/08/28/2012-football-rivalry-census-results/|title=2012–13 Football Rivalry Survey Results|date=28 August 2012|work=The Chris Whiting Show|access-date=25 January 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Reciprocally, Burnley considers their biggest rivalry to be with Blackburn.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/more-game-blackburn-vs-burnley|title=More Than A Game: Blackburn vs Burnley|date=1 May 2005|work=FourFourTwo|access-date=23 December 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref name="thedailycutter">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedaisycutter.co.uk/2012/09/football-rivalries-the-survey/|title=Football Rivalries: The Survey – The Daisy Cutter|date=14 September 2012|work=The Daisy Cutter|access-date=23 December 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> Games between them are known as the ''[[East Lancashire derby|East Lancashire Derby]]'', named after the region both clubs hail from, and it is known as one of the longest standing derbies in world football, as both clubs are founder members of the [[English Football League|Football League]] and have won the [[List of English football champions|First Division]] and the [[FA Cup]].
The two clubs are separated by fourteen miles (22.5 kilometres) and besides the geographical proximity, the clubs have a long-standing history of fierce rivalry too; their first competitive clash being a Football League match in 1888, in the [[1888–89 Football League|inaugural season]] of the competition.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://www.11v11.com/teams/burnley/tab/opposingTeams/opposition/Blackburn%20Rovers/|title=Burnley football club: record v Blackburn Rovers|last=|first=|date=|website=www.11v11.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref> Four years earlier, however, they had met for the first time, although in an alleged ''pre-league friendly'', with considerable pride at stake.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/4668181.History_of_the_Blackburn_Rovers_v_Burnley_derby__part_one/|title=History of the Blackburn Rovers v Burnley derby: part one|last=|first=|date=|website=Lancashire Telegraph|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref> Including the ''pre-league friendlies'', there have been 113 matches played between both, with Burnley having the slightly better head-to-head record of the two teams, ''the Clarets'' winning 48 games and Blackburn 45.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" /> Burnley's closest geographic rival is actually [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]] but, as they have never competed at the same level (although defunct club [[Accrington F.C.|Accrington]] did), there is no rivalry between both.
Other rivalries exist with local clubs [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]], [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] and [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]].<ref name="wordpress.com" /> Burnley have regularly played them in the league and cup competitions and the encounter between Burnley and Preston is, as of 2018–19, the most frequently played match in both club's histories.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.11v11.com/teams/burnley/tab/opposingTeams/opposition/Preston%20North%20End/|title=Burnley football club: record v Preston North End|last=|first=|date=|website=www.11v11.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref> ''The Clarets'' also contested heated matches with [[Halifax Town A.F.C.|Halifax Town]], [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] and [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] in the 1990s, when they were playing in the lower leagues, although feelings of animosity were mainly one-sided.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.footballfanscensus.com/issueresults/Club_Rivalries_Uncovered_Results.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=3 February 2004|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040203154108/http://www.footballfanscensus.com/issueresults/Club_Rivalries_Uncovered_Results.pdf|archive-date=3 February 2004|dead-url=yes|access-date=25 January 2018}}</ref>
Burnley will be the only club from the ceremonial county of [[Lancashire]] in the top flight during the [[2018–19 Burnley F.C. season|2018–19]] season, as they were in the previous two seasons. Their most local rivals will be West Yorkshire side [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]], who are based 25 miles (40 kilometres) away from Turf Moor.
==Honours==

==Records== {{Main|List of Burnley F.C. records and statistics}} [[File:Jerry Dawson.jpg|thumb|150px|Jerry Dawson, Burnley's current record holder for the highest number of league appearances.]] The holder of the record for the most appearances in all competitions for Burnley is goalkeeper [[Jerry Dawson (footballer, born 1888)|Jerry Dawson]], having made 569 first team appearances between 1907 and 1928.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/8814486.Plaque_to_be_created_to_honour_Claret_goalkeeping_legend/|title=Plaque to be created to honour Claret goalkeeping legend|last=|first=|date=|website=Lancashire Telegraph|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 August 2018}}</ref> The club's top goal scorer is [[George Beel]], who scored 187 goals from 1923 to 1932. He also holds the record for the most league goals scored in a season, 35 in the [[1927–28 Football League|1927–28]] season in the [[Football League First Division]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=435&teamTabs=records|title=All Time Burnley Records & Achievements|last=|first=|date=|website=www.soccerbase.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 August 2018}}</ref> [[Bert Freeman]] has scored the most goals in all official, competitive competitions in a single season, scoring 36 goals in the [[Football League Second Division]] and FA Cup in [[1912–13 in English football|1912–13]]. As of August 2018, Jimmy McIlroy is the most [[Cap (sport)|capped]] player while playing at Burnley, making 51 appearances for [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]] between 1951 and 1962.<ref name=":2" /> The first Burnley player to be capped was forward [[John Yates (footballer, born 1861)|John Yates]], who took to the field for [[England national football team|England]] against [[Ireland national football team (1882–1950)|Ireland]] at [[Anfield]] on 2 March 1889. He scored a [[hat-trick]], but despite this, he was never called up again.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/TeamPlyrsBios/PlayersXYZ/BioYatesJ.html|title=England Players – Jack Yates|last=|first=|date=|website=www.englandfootballonline.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 August 2018}}</ref>
The club's largest win in league football has been a 9–0 victory over [[Darwen F.C.|Darwen]] in the First Division in [[1891–92 Football League|1891–92]]. Burnley's largest victories in the FA Cup have been 9–0 wins over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] ([[1908–09 FA Cup|1908–09]]), [[New Brighton A.F.C.|New Brighton]] ([[1956–57 FA Cup|1956–57]]) and [[Penrith F.C.|Penrith]] ([[1984–85 FA Cup|1984–85]]).<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170315184511/http://www.statto.com/football/teams/burnley/records|title=Burnley scoring and sequence records|last=|first=|date=15 March 2017|website=Statto.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 August 2018}}</ref> The club's record defeat is an 11–0 loss to ''Darwen Old Wanderers'' in the FA Cup first round in the [[1885–86 FA Cup|1885–86]] season.<ref name=":3" />
Burnley's record home attendance is 54,775 for a third round FA Cup match against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] on 23 February 1924.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080309101845/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/History/0,,10413~1031447,00.html|title=The Turf Moor Story|last=|first=|date=9 March 2008|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 August 2018}}</ref> With the introduction of regulations enforcing all-seater stadiums, it is unlikely that this record will be beaten in the foreseeable future. Their longest ever unbeaten run in the league was between 6 September 1920 and 25 March 1921, to which they remained unbeaten for 30 games on their way to the [[1920–21 Burnley F.C. season|First Division title]]. It stood as the longest stretch without defeat in a single season in Football League history until [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] bettered it in 2003–04.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/burnley/5386898/10-things-you-probably-didnt-know-about-Burnley.html|title=10 things you probably didn't know about Burnley|last=Smith|first=Rory|date=26 May 2009|work=|access-date=11 August 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref>
The highest transfer fee received for a Burnley player is £25 million, from [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] for defender [[Michael Keane (footballer, born 1993)|Michael Keane]] in July 2017,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.burnleyexpress.net/sport/football/clarets/keane-desperate-to-face-clarets-1-8781418|title=Keane desperate to face Clarets|last=|first=|date=|work=Burnley Express|access-date=11 August 2018|language=en}}</ref> while the highest transfer fee paid by the club to date was both for forward [[Chris Wood (footballer, born 1991)|Chris Wood]] from [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] in August 2017 and for defender [[Ben Gibson]] from [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in August 2018, the pair were reported to be bought for a fee of £15 million each.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45076206|title=Ben Gibson: Burnley sign Middlesbrough centre-back for joint club record fee|last=|first=|date=5 August 2018|work=BBC Sport|access-date=11 August 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref> When forward [[Bob Kelly (footballer)|Bob Kelly]] moved from Burnley to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] for £6,550 in 1925, he broke the [[List of most expensive association football transfers|world football transfer record]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-soccer-transfers/evolution-of-world-record-transfers-since-1893-idUSKCN10K031|title=Evolution of world record transfers since 1893|last=|first=|date=9 August 2016|work=Reuters|access-date=11 August 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Overall league history=== {{Main|List of Burnley F.C. seasons}}As of the [[2018–19 Burnley F.C. season|2018–19]] season, Burnley have played 120 seasons in [[English football league system|English league football]]. 56 of these have been spent in the first tier '''(1)''' (most recently in 2018–19), 46 in the second '''(2)''' (most recently in 2015–16), eleven in the third '''(3)''' (most recently in 1999–2000) and seven in the fourth '''(4)''' (most recently in 1991–92).<ref name="eurostats" />

== Footnotes == {{refbegin}} :A. {{note|Topdivision}}Up until 1992, the top division of [[Football in England|English football]] was the [[Football League First Division]]. The Premier League took over from the First Division as the top tier of the [[English football league system]] upon its formation in 1992. The First Division then became the second tier of English football, the Second Division became the third tier, and so on. The First Division is now known as the [[Football League Championship]], while the Second Division is now known as [[Football League One]]. :B. {{note|Win%}}Win% is [[Rounding|rounded]] to [[Decimal|two decimal places]]. {{refend}}

updater|CardiffC}} | position = {{English football updater|CardiffC3}} | website = http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk | }} '''Cardiff City Football Club''' ({{lang-cy|Clwb Pêl-droed Dinas Caerdydd}}) is a professional [[association football]] club based in [[Cardiff]], Wales. The team compete in the [[Premier League]], the top tier of the [[English football league system]], as of the [[2018–19 Cardiff City F.C. season|2018–19 season]]. Founded in 1899 as Riverside A.F.C., the club changed its name to Cardiff City in 1908 and entered the [[Southern Football League]] in 1910 before joining the [[English Football League]] in 1920. The team's longest period in the top tier of English football came between 1921 and 1929. Since then, they have spent a total of nine seasons in the top flight, the most recent being in the current [[2018–19 Premier League|2018–19 Premier League season]].
The club is the only team from outside England to have won the [[FA Cup]], doing so in [[1927 FA Cup Final|1927]]. They have also reached three other cup finals in English competitions, the [[1925 FA Cup Final]] against [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], the [[2008 FA Cup Final]] against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] and the [[2012 Football League Cup Final]] against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], suffering defeat on each occasion. They have won the [[Welsh Cup]] on 22 occasions, making them the second most successful team in the competition's history behind [[Wrexham A.F.C.|Wrexham]].
With the exception of a short period this century, the team have played in home colours of blue and white since 1908, which gives them the nickname "The Bluebirds". The club's first permanent ground was [[Ninian Park]] opened in 1910; it remained in use for 99 years until the club moved into the [[Cardiff City Stadium]] in 2009. Cardiff have long-standing rivalries with nearby clubs [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], known as the [[South Wales derby]] and [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]], known as the [[Severnside derby]]. The club's record appearance holder is [[Billy Hardy (footballer)|Billy Hardy]], who made 590 appearances in a 20 year playing spell with Cardiff, and their record goalscorer is [[Len Davies]] with 179 goals.
==History== {{main article|History of Cardiff City F.C.}}
===Early years (1899–1920)=== Following a meeting at the home of [[Lithography|lithographic]] artist [[Bartley Wilson]] in Cardiff,<ref name="Hayes208">{{harvnb|Hayes|2006|p=208}}</ref> the club was founded in 1899 as Riverside A.F.C. as a way of keeping players from the Riverside Cricket Club together and in shape during the winter months.<ref name="obscure">{{cite web |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/obscure-story-cardiff-citys-blue-2030463 |title=The obscure story of Cardiff City's blue kit and nickname |website=WalesOnline |publisher=[[Media Wales]] |first=Steve |last=Tucker |date=9 May 2012 |accessdate=21 August 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170822012209/http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/obscure-story-cardiff-citys-blue-2030463 |archive-date=22 August 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="Hayes5">{{harvnb|Hayes|2003|p=5}}</ref> In their first season, they played [[Exhibition game|friendlies]] against local sides at their [[Sophia Gardens]] ground. In 1900 they joined the Cardiff & District League for their first competitive season.<ref>{{harvnb|Grandin|2010|p=11}}</ref> When [[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|King Edward VII]] granted Cardiff city status in 1905, the club put in a request to the [[South Wales and Monmouthshire Football Association]] to change their name to Cardiff City.<ref name="obscure"/> The request was turned down as they were deemed not to be playing at a high enough level. To enhance their standing, the team arranged to join the South Wales Amateur League in 1907. The following year they were granted permission to change the name of the club to Cardiff City.<ref name="Shepherd4">{{harvnb|Shepherd|2002|p=4}}</ref><ref name="99–20">{{cite web |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/article/1899-1920-724134.aspx |title=1899–1920 Foundations & the Early Years |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |first=Richard |last=Shepherd |date=19 March 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160622141513/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk//news/article/1899-1920-724134.aspx |archive-date=22 June 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Although growing in stature, the club was forced to turn down the opportunity to join the newly formed Second Division of the [[Southern Football League]] due to a lack of facilities at their Sophia Gardens ground. Over the next two years, Cardiff played friendlies against some of Britain's top professional sides, including [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]], [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] and [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]]. The matches were played at various grounds in Cardiff and nearby towns so as to gauge the level of public interest in the team.<ref name="grandin12">{{harvnb|Grandin|2010|p=12}}</ref> The club eventually secured land to build their own stadium, [[Ninian Park]], which was completed in 1910. The club turned professional the same year. They made their first signing the following year with the acquisition of [[Jack Evans (Welsh footballer)|Jack Evans]] from fellow Welsh side Cwmparc.<ref name="99–20"/>
With the new grounds in place, Cardiff joined the Southern Football League Second Division<ref name="FCHD">{{cite web |url=http://fchd.info/CARDIFFC.HTM |title=Cardiff City |publisher=Football Club History Database |accessdate=22 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170424201828/http://www.fchd.info/CARDIFFC.HTM |archive-date=24 April 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and appointed their first manager, [[Davy McDougall]], who became [[player-manager]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Playing Manager Appointed|newspaper=Evening Express|page=4|date=14 September 1910}}</ref> They went on to finish in fourth place in their first year in the league. The board decided to replace McDougall with [[Fred Stewart (football manager)|Fred Stewart]], who had previous managerial experience with [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]].<ref name="Hayes208"/> He set about adopting a more professional approach, signing several players with Football League experience, including brothers [[John Burton (footballer, born 1885)|John]] and [[George Burton (footballer)|George Burton]] and [[Billy Hardy (footballer)|Billy Hardy]]. Stewart led the team to promotion in his second season by winning the Second Division title. They remained in the First Division for the next decade, and finished in the top four on two occasions.<ref name="99–20"/><ref>{{harvnb|Shepherd|2002|pages=14–21}}</ref>
===1920s success and later decline (1920–1945)=== In 1920, the club submitted a successful application to join the [[English Football League|Football League]] and were placed into the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] for the [[1920–21 in English football|1920–21 season]].<ref name="99–20"/> Stewart brought in several players with Football League experience, breaking the club's transfer record on two occasions to sign [[Jimmy Gill]] and later [[Jimmy Blair (footballer, born 1888)|Jimmy Blair]] from [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|The Wednesday]]. They played their first match in the Football League on 28 August 1920, defeating Stockport County 5–2.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/2017/august/history--the-significance-of-opening-day/ |title=Opening Day History – Starting with success |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |date=1 August 2017 |accessdate=9 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170909143307/https://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/2017/august/history--the-significance-of-opening-day/ |archive-date=9 September 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The side finished the season in second place to win promotion to the [[Football League First Division|First Division]].<ref name="FCHD"/> They finished behind [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] on [[Goal difference|goal average]], and reached the semi-final of the [[FA Cup]].<ref name="20–47">{{cite web |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/article/1920-1947-724302.aspx |title=1920–1947 Great Days, Lows & Recovery |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |first=Richard |last=Shepherd |date=19 March 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160626092929/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk//news/article/1920-1947-724302.aspx |archive-date=26 June 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In their third season in the top-tier, the team finished runners-up to [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] because of a goal average difference of 0.024.<ref name="FCHD"/><ref name="20–47"/><ref name=autogeneratedqos>{{cite web|first=Kirk |last=McLean |title=Queens Legends: George McLachlan and the 1936 Overseas tour |url=http://www.qosfc.com/AboutUs/QueensLegends/tabid/115/Default.aspx |publisher=Queen of the South F.C. |accessdate=14 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226192017/http://www.qosfc.com/AboutUs/QueensLegends/tabid/115/Default.aspx |archivedate=26 February 2009 }}</ref> Cardiff drew their final match 0–0 as club record goalscorer [[Len Davies]] missed a penalty.<ref name="20–47"/>
[[File:CardiffCityFC League Performance.svg|thumb|320px|Yearly table position since Cardiff City joined the Football League<ref name="FCHD"/>]] The [[1924–25 in English football|following season]] was the first time Cardiff appeared at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]], having reached their first FA Cup final.<ref name="FCHD"/> The team lost 1–0 to [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] following a goal from [[England national football team|England]] international [[Fred Tunstall]].<ref name="20–47"/> The [[1926–27 in English football|1926–27]] season was Cardiff's worst performance in the top tier of English Football since winning promotion six seasons prior, finishing in 14th position. However, they reached their second FA Cup final in the space of two years.<ref name="20–47"/> On [[St George's Day]], 23 April 1927, at Wembley Stadium in London, Cardiff became the only non-English side to win the FA Cup by defeating [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] 1–0 in the [[1927 FA Cup Final|final]];<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7328650.stm |title=Cup friends reunited |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |first=Peter |last=Shuttleworth |date=4 January 2009 |accessdate=1 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170901205505/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7328650.stm |archive-date=1 September 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Hughie Ferguson]] scored the only goal of the game in the 74th minute. He received the ball from [[Ernie Curtis]] and hurried a tame shot toward the goal;<ref>{{harvnb|Hayes|2006|p=63}}</ref> [[Dan Lewis (footballer)|Dan Lewis]], the Arsenal goalkeeper, allowed the shot to slip through his grasp and knocked the ball into the net with his elbow.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/happy-anniversary-cardiff-city-celebrate-2995570 |title=Happy anniversary: Cardiff City celebrate 86 years since their 1927 FA Cup win |work=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |last=Rogers |first=Gareth |date=23 April 2013 |accessdate=22 February 2019}}</ref> Captain [[Fred Keenor]] received the FA Cup trophy at the end of the match from [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]] only seven years after Cardiff City had entered the Football League.<ref name="20–47"/> When the team returned to Cardiff the next day, a crowd of around 150,000 people lined the streets to welcome them.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cup Winners Mobbed|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000329/19270426/084/0007|accessdate=9 August 2016|work=[[Western Morning News]]|issue=20932|date=26 April 1927|page=7|subscription=yes|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]}}</ref>
The side also won the [[Welsh Cup]] in 1927 defeating [[Rhyl F.C.|Rhyl]] 2–0. They went on to win the [[FA Charity Shield]] after beating amateur side [[Corinthian F.C.|the Corinthians]] 2–1 at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]].<ref>{{harvnb|Shepherd|2002|p=28}}</ref><ref name="20–47"/><ref>{{harvnb|Shepherd|2002|p=29}}</ref> However, the club entered a period of decline after their cup success. They were relegated from the First Division in the [[1928-29 in English football|1928–29]] season, despite conceding fewer goals than any other side in the division.<ref name="28–29_table">{{cite web |url=http://www.englishfootballleaguetables.co.uk/final/f1928-29.html |title=Final Table for season 1928–29 |publisher=English Football League Tables |accessdate=22 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202005003/http://www.englishfootballleaguetables.co.uk/final/f1928-29.html |archive-date=2 February 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> They suffered a second relegation two years later, dropping into the [[Football League Third Division South|Third Division South]] for the first time since they joined the Football League.<ref name="FCHD"/> During their first season in the division, Cardiff recorded their biggest-ever win when they beat [[Thames A.F.C.|Thames]] by a scoreline of 9–2.<ref>{{harvnb|Shepherd|2002|p=3}}</ref> They finished the [[1932–33 in English football|1932–33 season]] in 19th place, resulting in manager Fred Stewart tendering his resignation from his post after 22 years in charge.<ref name="20–47"/> Club founder Bartley Wilson stepped in to replace Stewart. Results continued to be disappointing, however, and in March 1934, [[Ben Watts-Jones]] was given the opportunity to manage the club he had supported as a youngster. He was unable to turn the team's fortunes around by the end of the season, and Cardiff City were forced to apply for re-election after finishing bottom of the division.<ref name="Hayes208"/> Watts-Jones remained in charge for another three years until [[Billy Jennings (Welsh footballer)|Bill Jennings]] replaced him. Cardiff remained in the Third Division South until the Football League was suspended following the outbreak of [[World War II|World War II]].<ref name="FCHD"/><ref name="20–47"/>
===Post war and European competition (1945–2000)=== In their first season since the resumption of the Football League, under new manager [[Billy McCandless]], Cardiff finished the [[1946–47 in English football|1946–47]] season as champions of the Third Division South and returned to the Second Division.<ref>{{harvnb|Hayes|2006|p=209}}</ref> McCandless left the club soon after and was replaced by [[Cyril Spiers]] who led the side to promotion in the [[1951–52 in English football|1951–52]] season.<ref name="FCHD"/><ref name="47–64">{{cite web |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/article/1947-1964-726695.aspx |title=1947–1964 Post-War Recovery |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |first=Richard |last=Shepherd |date=20 March 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160530142533/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk//news/article/1947-1964-726695.aspx |archive-date=30 May 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Cardiff returned to the top tier of English football for the first time in 23 years and stayed there for five seasons. <ref name="20–47"/> They were relegated after in 1957, after struggling in the bottom half of the table for three seasons.<ref name="47–64"/> They returned to the First Division for two seasons between 1960 and 1962 before they were again relegated.<ref name="FCHD"/>
[[File:Canton End at Ninian Park geograph-2999342-by-Steve-Daniels.jpg|thumb|right|Cardiff City playing [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] at [[Ninian Park]] in 1983|alt=A black and white image of a football match.]] During the 1960s, Cardiff participated in [[UEFA competitions|European competition]] for the first time as a result of winning the Welsh Cup, which granted qualification to the newly created [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup|European Cup Winners Cup]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablese/ec2.html |title=European Cup Winners' Cup |publisher=The Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation |last=Stokkermans |first=Karel |accessdate=13 February 2019}}</ref> Their first ever match in European competition was in the tournament during the 1964–65 season against Danish side [[Esbjerg fB]]. The team won 1–0 on aggregate over two legs, the only goal being scored by [[Peter King (footballer born 1943)|Peter King]].<ref>{{harvnb|Shepherd|2002|p=64}}</ref> They went on to reach the quarter-finals before being knocked out by [[Real Zaragoza]].<ref name="FCHD"/> Despite their exploits in Europe, the team were still struggling in league competition under the stewardship of [[Jimmy Scoular]], finishing in 20th position in the Second Division.<ref name="64–73">{{cite web |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/article/1964-1973-727297.aspx |title=1964–1973 the Scoular Years |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |first=Richard |last=Shepherd |date=21 March 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131030052008/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/article/1964-1973-727297.aspx |archive-date=30 October 2013 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Two years later the team reached the semi-final of the Cup Winners Cup after victories over [[Shamrock Rovers F.C.|Shamrock Rovers]], [[NAC Breda]], and [[Torpedo Moscow]] set up a tie with German side [[Hamburger SV|Hamburg]],<ref name="FCHD"/> whose squad contained a number of [[Germany national football team|German]] internationals. This remains the furthest any Welsh side has advanced in European competition.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wfda.co.uk/index.php/europe/welsh-club-records |title=Welsh clubs in Europe |publisher=Welsh Football Data Archive |accessdate=9 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170909142303/http://wfda.co.uk/index.php/europe/welsh-club-records |archive-date=9 September 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> After a 1–1 draw in the first leg, over 43,000 fans turned out at Ninian Park to watch Hamburg win 3–2.<ref name="64–73"/><ref>{{harvnb|Shepherd|2002|p=67}}</ref> During the [[1970-71 in English football|1970–71]] season, Cardiff reached the quarter-finals of the Cup Winners Cup where they faced Spanish side [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]. The first leg of the tie was held at Ninian Park where 47,000 fans watched one of the most significant victories in Cardiff's history when [[Brian Clark (footballer born 1943)|Brian Clark]] headed in to give Cardiff a 1–0 win.<ref name="Shepherd4"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/8002524.stm |title=1971 – Cardiff City 1–0 Real Madrid |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Peter |last=Shuttleworth |accessdate=9 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170909143547/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/8002524.stm |archive-date=9 September 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> They were later eliminated after losing the second leg 2–0.<ref name="64–73"/> The team remained in the Second Division for 19 of the 20 seasons between 1962 and 1982. They were relegated to the Third Division for one season during the 1975–76 season.<ref name="FCHD"/><ref name="74–89">{{cite web |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/article/1974-1989-727524.aspx |title=Friday Fame & 80s Pain |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |first=Richard |last=Shepherd |date=21 March 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160627002053/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk//news/article/1974-1989-727524.aspx |archive-date=27 June 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Cardiff were continuously in the lower two divisions of the Football League between 1985 and 1993. The club appointed several managers in attempts to turn the team's performances around with limited success.<ref name="74–89"/> They were relegated to the [[Football League Fourth Division|Fourth Division]] once in the [[1985-86 in English football|1985–86]] season and, despite returning to the Third Division on two occasions, they finished in their lowest-ever league position in [[1995–96 in English football|1996]] – 22nd of 24 in Division Three.<ref name="89–99">{{cite web |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/article/1989-1999-727864.aspx |title=1989–1999 From Darkness into Light? |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |first=Richard |last=Shepherd |date=21 March 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818052448/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/article/1989-1999-727864.aspx |archive-date=18 August 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 1995, Cardiff and other Welsh clubs competing in English leagues were banned from entering the Welsh Cup by the [[Football Association of Wales]] after pressure from [[UEFA]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/17346143 |title=FAW seeks route into Europe for Cardiff and Swansea |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 March 2012 |accessdate=9 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171111095425/http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/17346143 |archive-date=11 November 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> who did not want teams playing in two national cup competitions.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/13160744 |title=Cardiff City tempted by Welsh Cup return |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 April 2011 |accessdate=9 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181024045706/https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/13160744 |archive-date=24 October 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Their final match in the competition was a 2–1 defeat to Wrexham in the [[1995 Welsh Cup Final|1995 final]].<ref name="FCHD"/>
===Foreign investment (2000–present)=== In August 2000, Lebanese businessman [[Sam Hammam]] purchased control of the club and replaced Steve Borley as chairman.<ref name="Ignition">{{cite web |url=https://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/2013/march/2000-2010-ignition--progression/ |title=2000–2010 Ignition & Progression |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |first=Richard |last=Shepherd |date=21 March 2013 |accessdate=12 August 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170812211220/https://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/2013/march/2000-2010-ignition--progression/ |archive-date=12 August 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="chairmen">{{Cite news |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/court-hearing-just-latest-sad-2209203 |title=Court hearing is just latest sad tale in Bluebird board wrangling |work=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |last=Phillips |first=Terry |date=6 December 2007 |accessdate=25 February 2019}}</ref> Shortly after taking over, he controversially pledged to get the entire Welsh nation to support Cardiff by renaming the club "The Cardiff Celts" and changing the club colours to green, red and white.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2000/aug/08/newsstory.sport2 |title=Hammam dreams of Wales United |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |first=Grahame |last=Lloyd |date=8 August 2000 |accessdate=12 August 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170812174253/https://www.theguardian.com/football/2000/aug/08/newsstory.sport2 |archive-date=12 August 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> After lengthy talks with senior players and fans, he decided the best policy was not to change the name of the club. The club crest was redesigned; the new design incorporated the Cardiff City bluebird in front of the [[Flag of Saint David]] and featured the club's nickname superimposed at the top of the crest.<ref name="Historical Kits">{{cite web |title=Cardiff City |url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Cardiff_City/Cardiff_City.htm |work=Historical Football Kits |publisher=Dave Moor |accessdate=19 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170917080434/http://historicalkits.co.uk/Cardiff_City/Cardiff_City.htm |archive-date=17 September 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Hammam funded the transfers of several new players to the club, and new manager [[Lennie Lawrence]] guided Cardiff to promotion when they won the Second Division play-off in [[2002–03 in English football|2003]] against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/david-conn-cardiff-brought-to-their-knees-as-financial-reality-bites-for-hammam-527221.html |title=David Conn: Cardiff brought to their knees as financial reality bites for Hammam |newspaper=The Independent |first=David |last=Conn |date=5 March 2005 |accessdate=12 August 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170812172733/http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/david-conn-cardiff-brought-to-their-knees-as-financial-reality-bites-for-hammam-527221.html |archive-date=12 August 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Substitute [[Andy Campbell]] came off the bench to score the only goal in extra time and ensure Cardiff's return to Division One after an 18-year absence.<ref name="Ignition"/>
The club experienced increasing financial difficulties over the next few years and plans for a new stadium failed to gain approval from [[Cardiff Council]] because of concerns over financial security in 2006.<ref name="Ignition"/> Hammam then agreed to a takeover by a consortium led by new chairman [[Peter Ridsdale]] and the lead developer of the new stadium, Paul Guy.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/6205951.stm |title=Hammam accused of Cardiff 'greed' |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 December 2006 |accessdate=3 January 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070126022554/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/6205951.stm |archive-date=26 January 2007 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> During the 2007–08 season, Cardiff reached the semi-final of the FA Cup for the first time in 81 years after beating Middlesbrough 2–0 on 9 March 2008.<ref name="Ignition"/> After coming through their semi-final against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] with a 1–0 win at [[Wembley Stadium]] on 6 April with a goal from [[Joe Ledley]],<ref>{{cite news |last=McKenzie |first=Andrew |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/7326118.stm |title=Barnsley 0–1 Cardiff City (FA Cup Semi-final) |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 April 2008 |accessdate=3 January 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307133725/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/7326118.stm |archive-date=7 March 2009 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> they eventually lost 1–0 to [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] in the final.<ref name="Ignition"/>
